dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A BOY runs across the dark, flat wilderness of the North Kent marshes. A bitterly cold December evening, the misty light is fading and the boy races as if trying to outrun the darkness. This is PHILLIP PIRRIP - ‘PIP’. He is eight years-old.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A small, squat church sinks on the boggy ground. A yew tree - PIP snaps off a twig and adds it to the forlorn bunch of wintery sticks he carries. A modest tombstone bears the inscription; Here lies PHILLIP PIRRIP late of this Parish. Also GEORGIANA, wife of the above. Also ALEXANDER, BARTHOLOMEW TOBIAS, ABRAHAM, ROGER. Five tiny lozenge-shaped graves mark the childrens’ final resting place. PIP lays his modest tribute and sets about brushing away the weeds and dead-leaves that clutter the grave - - as an IMMENSE FIGURE looms behind him and snatches him up. PIP goes to cry out, but a filthy hand is clamped across his mouth as he is hoisted, weeping and struggling into the air.

dialogues.speaker: THE CONVICT
dialogues.text: Hold your noise! Hold your noise, you little devil, or I'll cut your throat! The convict is a formidable figure, immense and terrifying, his head and face brutally shaven and scarred His name is MAGWITCH, though we won’t hear this spoken aloud for some time.

dialogues.speaker: MAGWITCH
dialogues.text: Tell us your, name! Quick!

dialogues.speaker: PIP
dialogues.text: Pip!

dialogues.speaker: MAGWITCH
dialogues.text: Once more! Give it mouth!

dialogues.speaker: PIP
dialogues.text: Pip! Pip, sir!  GREAT EXPECTATIONS (PAGES 10/12) 2. Then PIP is flipped upside down, held by his ankles, shaken.

dialogues.speaker: MAGWITCH
dialogues.text: Got wittles on you, boy? Tell me!

dialogues.speaker: PIP
dialogues.text: No, sir! - then upright again, he’s seated on a tombstone, his tiny face held in massive, manacled hands.

dialogues.speaker: MAGWITCH
dialogues.text: What fat cheeks you ha’got. Darn me if I couldn’t eat em. Where’s your mother?

dialogues.speaker: PIP
dialogues.text: There, sir! (MAGWITCH flinches -) ‘Also Georgiana’, with my father. ‘late of this parish’. My brothers too.

dialogues.speaker: MAGWITCH
dialogues.text: An orphan, eh? Who d’you live with? That's supposin’ I let you live.

dialogues.speaker: PIP
dialogues.text: My sister, sir - Mrs Joe Gargery, wife of Joe Gargery, the blacksmith, sir...

dialogues.speaker: MAGWITCH
dialogues.text: Blacksmith, eh? (a moment) You know what a file is?

dialogues.speaker: PIP
dialogues.text: Yes, sir.

dialogues.speaker: MAGWITCH
dialogues.text: And you know what wittles is?

dialogues.speaker: PIP
dialogues.text: Yes, sir, food, sir.

dialogues.speaker: MAGWITCH
dialogues.text: (breath hot on PIP’s face) Now I ain’t alone, as you may think I am. There’s a young man hid with me in comparison with which I am an angel, has a secret way of getting at a boy, and at his heart, and at his liver, so that they may be roasted and ate. It is in vain for a boy to hide from that young man. A boy may lock his door, may tuck himself up, may draw the clothes over his head, and that young man will softly creep and creep his way to him and tear him open... (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: MAGWITCH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (whispers in the ear of the terrified boy) You bring me tomorrow morning early, at yonder battery, that file and them wittles - never daring to say a word - and I will do what I can to keep that young man out of your insides. Understand? (PIP nods) Speak it out!

dialogues.speaker: PIP
dialogues.text: Yes, sir!

dialogues.speaker: MAGWITCH
dialogues.text: Now. Get you home. PIP turns, tumbles away, pausing just long enough to turn and see the convict disappear into the misty graveyard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PIP runs towards home as fast as he can. His stride slows A gibbet hangs over the road, empty but still sinister in the gathering gloom. PIP steps warily beneath, then starts to run once again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PIP’s home adjoins the forge. Made of wood, the house is modest but comfortable enough, and a safe refuge now. PIP barrels towards the door, and straight into -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JOE GARGERY, the blacksmith - a rich Kentish accent.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: There you are! Your sister’s been out a dozen times looking for you, old chap. And on cue, a ferocious cry comes from outside.

dialogues.speaker: PIP
dialogues.text: With practiced efficiency, JOE takes a towel, wads it up, uses it to pad the back of PIP’s trousers.  GREAT EXPECTATIONS (PAGES 10/12) 4.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: She’s on the rampage, Pip, and she’s got Tickler with her. Best get behind the door, old chap. I’1l do my best... A closer look at JOE - fair, curly hair, pale eyes, he’s large, powerfully-built man, devoid of aggression, incapable of malice. Good-natured; child-like almost. And then MRS JOE is in the room. Ferocious, black-hair, red-faced with fury.

dialogues.speaker: MRS JOE
dialogues.text: Where have you been, you little monkey! Wearing me out with fret and worry! I said where have you been! She charges at PIP, wielding her cane, ‘Tickler’. JOE doe his best to shield PIP behind his large leg, but MRS JOE simply beats him too.

dialogues.speaker: PIP
dialogues.text: The churchyard! As it was Christmas -

dialogues.speaker: MRS JOE
dialogues.text: The churchyard! If it weren’t for me you’d’ve been to the churchyard years ago, and stayed there! Who brought you up by hand?

dialogues.speaker: PIP
dialogues.text: You did!

dialogues.speaker: MRS JOE
dialogues.text: And why did I do it, I should like to know!

dialogues.speaker: PIP
dialogues.text: I don’t know.

dialogues.speaker: MRS JOE
dialogues.text: Gargery - fetch the tar water!

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: No need for tar water (she turns on JOE) It is Christmas, my love.

dialogues.speaker: MRS JOE
dialogues.text: (a moment then -) Bad enough having to be a blacksmith’s wife, without having to mother you too. Ha! Churchyard! (sawing at a loaf of bread) You’1l drive me to the churchyard between you one of these days, and a precious pair you’d be without me! But you’d like that I suppose, the both of you...

dialogues.speaker: GREAT EXPECTATIONS, (PAGES 10/12)
dialogues.text: And as her monologue continues, PIP slides out from his hiding place and exchanges looks with his ally JOE. A mute conversation; ‘you alright, old chap?’, ‘thank you Joe’. JOE ruffles his hair; an understanding. But MRS JOE is watching. MRS JOE. Table! Now! They take their places at the table. PIP eyes the bread. The sound of a cannon in the distance distracts JOE, and PIP snatches the bread, stows it beneath the table.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Hear that? (another distant explosion) There’s a conwict escaped off the Hulks.

dialogues.speaker: PIP
dialogues.text: What might he have done, this convict? And MRS JOE is on him again.

dialogues.speaker: MRS JOE
dialogues.text: Murder most likely. That’s why they’re put in the Hulks, because they murder-

dialogues.speaker: PIP
dialogues.text: Murder?

dialogues.speaker: MRS JOE
dialogues.text: - murder and rob and ask too many questions! (points the knife) Where’s that bread gone? It’s in his hand, beneath the table -

dialogues.speaker: PIP
dialogues.text: I ate it. A moment. MRS JOE glares but PIP holds his nerve and she turns. JOE regards PIP questioningly. PIP shrugs, and squeezes the bread into his pocket. INT. PIP’S BEDROOM - NIGHT 6 Hungry, terrified, PIP hides beneath the covers, thinking on murder. Every object in the small, meek attic room seems menacing, every creak seems to speak ‘murder’.PIP pulls the covers higher, squeezes his eyes shut.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sun rising on the new day.  10 11 GREAT EXPECTATIONS (PAGES 10/12) 6.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Every floorboard creaks as PIP tip-toes past JOE and MRS JOE's bedroom. A glimpse through the door - his sister snoring.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PIP lifts the lid from a stoneware pot and removes a magnificent meat-pie. Brandy is poured from bottle to flask, the flask corked, the bottle now half-full. PIP thinks a moment, tops the bottle up with a filthy viscous liquid - tar water. He shakes the bottle in the hope of hiding the deception. PIP turns and jumps; a dead hare hangs from the ceiling, its glassy eyes glaring accusingly at the young thief.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Christmas Day is damp and misty as PIP hurries guiltily towards the old fort that is their rendezvous. A seated figure is visible through the mist - THE CONVICT is slumped, cold and miserable, on a stone, inspecting the wounds caused by his manacles. PIP approaches, gathers his nerves, and touches the man on hi shoulder. The figure turns - But it’s a different CONVICT; gaunt, sinister, with cruel brooding eyes and a livid bruise on his face. He swipes at PIP with his chained hands, and PIP turns an flees, the hunched figure hobbling after him, growling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Breathless, PIP stumbles on, relieved to see that the cannibalistic young man has gone, for the moment at least But suddenly -

dialogues.speaker: MAGWITCH
dialogues.text: Well, did you bring it boy? MAGWITCH scoops PIP up into the air.

dialogues.speaker: PIP
dialogues.text: (handing over the bag) Yes, sir. Here, sir.  GREAT EXPECTATIONS (PAGES 10/12) 7.

dialogues.speaker: MAGWITCH
dialogues.text: And what’s in the bottle?

dialogues.speaker: PIP
dialogues.text: Brandy. Back on the ground, PIP watches MAGWITCH drain the bottle of brandy, then set about the pie, scooping great handful into his mouth, glaring about him like a starving dog protecting his food.

dialogues.speaker: MAGWITCH
dialogues.text: You brought no-one with you?

dialogues.speaker: PIP
dialogues.text: No, sir!

dialogues.speaker: MAGWITCH
dialogues.text: And asked no-one to follow?

dialogues.speaker: PIP
dialogues.text: I would not do that, sir. MAGWITCH’s eyes burn into PIP. Finally -

dialogues.speaker: MAGWITCH
dialogues.text: I believe you. A cold-hearted hound you’d be, at your time of life, to hunt down a wretch as near to death and dunghill as me. PIP, despite himself, is encouraged by the approval.

dialogues.speaker: PIP
dialogues.text: I’m glad you enjoy the pie.

dialogues.speaker: MAGWITCH
dialogues.text: Thankee, my boy, I do.

dialogues.speaker: PIP
dialogues.text: There’1l be none left for him!

dialogues.speaker: MAGWITCH
dialogues.text: For ‘him’? Who’s ‘him’?

dialogues.speaker: PIP
dialogues.text: The young man you spoke of. Who wants to eat my liver.

dialogues.speaker: MAGWITCH
dialogues.text: Oh, him? (Laughs-) He won’t want no pie.

dialogues.speaker: PIP
dialogues.text: He looked as if he did.  12 GREAT EXPECTATIONS (PAGES 10/12) 8.

dialogues.speaker: MAGWITCH
dialogues.text: Looked? What d’you mean, looked?

dialogues.speaker: PIP
dialogues.text: I saw him.

dialogues.speaker: MAGWITCH
dialogues.text: When?

dialogues.speaker: PIP
dialogues.text: Just now.

dialogues.speaker: MAGWITCH
dialogues.text: Where?

dialogues.speaker: PIP
dialogues.text: Down by the river.

dialogues.speaker: MAGWITCH
dialogues.text: Dressed like me? Bruised face? Here? Badly bruised? (PIP nods) Give me the file, boy! Immediately MAGWITCH is sawing wildly at his chains, oblivious to the raw red wounds about his ankles, muttering to himself. MAGWITCH (CONT’D) PIP Hunt him down like a Goodbye, then sir. A merry bloodhound I will. Let him Christmas to you! go free? Let him make a Goodbye... tool of me again and again? That villain? No, I’1l take him to the bottom of the river if I have to drag him there myself... And getting no response, PIP shrinks away into the mist. A Christmas carol, sung with great volume and little tune

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A squeeze-box wheezes away. The carol is performed by MR PUMBLECHOOK and the GARGERY’s other Christmas guests; MR and MRS WOPSLE and MR and MRS HUBBLE. These clerks and tradesmen are what pass as gentle-folk in the narrow confines of the village, and MRS JOE is appropriately puffed-up. PIP does his best to slip in un-noticed, but MRS JOE sees him, and discreetly draws her finger across her neck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Later. The Christmas dinner is laid. PUMBLECHOOK dominate the festivities, a large man with dull eyes and a mouth like a fish.

dialogues.speaker: PUMBLECHOOK
dialogues.text: For the great feast that we are about to receive - thanks to you ma‘am - may the good lord make us truly thankful.

dialogues.speaker: ALL
dialogues.text: Amen.

dialogues.speaker: MRS JOE
dialogues.text: Did you hear that? Be grateful!

dialogues.speaker: PUMBLECHOOK
dialogues.text: - especially, my boy, to those as what brought you up by hand.

dialogues.speaker: MRS HUBBLE
dialogues.text: Why is it that the young are never grateful? A moment’s contemplation of this devastating gambit.

dialogues.speaker: PUMBLECHOOK
dialogues.text: Naturally wicious! Mumbles of ‘true, true’! PIP is in hell, but JOE is there JUMP CUT - Meal underway, PIP picking at fat and gristle.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: More gravy, old chap?

dialogues.speaker: MRS JOE
dialogues.text: Oh, I nearly forgot! Ladies and gentleman, do leave a little room for the savoury pork pie so kindly provided for by dear Mr Pumblechook.

dialogues.speaker: PUMBLECHOOK
dialogues.text: No more than you deserve, ma’am.

dialogues.speaker: MRS JOE
dialogues.text: I’ll get it now. Shall I get it now? I’11l get it now. Murmurs of approval. She heads off to the larder to searc for the treasured pie, now long gone. PIP shrinks further in his seat.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: You look awful white, old chap. Have some gravy —  13 14 GREAT EXPECTATIONS (PAGES 10/12) 10.

dialogues.speaker: PUMBLECHOOK MRS JOE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: I often say, a slice of It’s here somewhere! savoury pork pie will lie on top of anything you care to mention and do no harm.

dialogues.speaker: MRS HUBBLE
dialogues.text: Wise words, as always.

dialogues.speaker: PUMBLECHOOK
dialogues.text: Especially with a little brandy.... MRS JOE returns —

dialogues.speaker: MRS JOE
dialogues.text: At least it was here. It’s gone! And now PUMBLECHOOK explodes into coughing and retching.

dialogues.speaker: PUMBLECHOOK
dialogues.text: TAR WATER! In the brandy! It’s all too much. He bolts to the door, dodging MRS JOE

dialogues.speaker: MRS JOE
dialogues.text: Come here, you little monkey! And straight into the arms of - A SERGEANT. A crowd of SOLDIERS stand behind him, rifles at the ready. In the SERGEANT’s hand, MAGWITCH’s manacles

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JOE’s hammer bangs down onto glowing iron. Sparks fly. Th party guests and the SOLDIERS are clustered round the forge as the chain of the manacles is repaired

dialogues.speaker: SERGEANT
dialogues.text: A nasty pair. Two of the most vicious characters you’d care to meet. Anybody here seen anything of any such game? (with a great hiss, the mManacles are plunged into the water) Thank you, sir. A fine job. (examines JOE’s handiwork, tests their strength.) We found them filed clean through. No matter. We'll have’em back on him soon enough. ‘Course, if any of you gentlemen fancy some sport...  15 16

dialogues.speaker: 16A
dialogues.text: 17 GREAT EXPECTATIONS (PAGES 10/12) 11. PIP regards JOE, and the possibility of larks - then MRS JOE, still glaring dangerously. No contest -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As night creeps in, so does the fog. The SOLDIERS advance in loose formation, a long line almost lost to each other in the mist. PIP and JOE pass beneath the old gibbet, PIP regarding it with dread. A whisper -—

dialogues.speaker: PIP
dialogues.text: I hope we don’t find ‘em, Joe.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: I hope so too, old chap.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The hunt continues. Voices from the mist -

dialogues.speaker: VOICE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Murder! Help! Help me! Murder!

dialogues.speaker: SOLDIER, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Over here! They’re over here. Get some light. Torches are lit ablaze now, their sulphurous flames glowing in the fog as the soldiers, JOE and PIP head to -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A ferocious fight is taking place, with MAGWITCH looming huge and victorious over his slighter opponent. The second CONVICT’s face is a mess of mud and blood, wit a vicious gash down one side of his face, the fight so brutal that the SOLDIERS can only stand and watch, too frightened to intervene, spectators in a flame-lit arena. The SERGEANT pushes through -—  GREAT EXPECTATIONS (PAGES 10/12) 12.

dialogues.speaker: SERGEANT
dialogues.text: Well what are you waiting for? Move! The SOLDIERS pull them apart, the two CONVICTS swearing and clawing at each other throughout.

dialogues.speaker: MAGWITCH
dialogues.text: I took him! Take note, I took him and gave him up to you!

dialogues.speaker: SERGEANT
dialogues.text: Handcuffs! The CONVICTS are manacled. PIP hides behind JOE’s leg.

dialogues.speaker: CONVICT
dialogues.text: He tried to murder me!

dialogues.speaker: MAGWITCH
dialogues.text: Try, and not do it? I'd have killed him if I wanted, but instead I dragged him here. I took him! Let him go free? Let him profit from me, again and again?

dialogues.speaker: SERGEANT
dialogues.text: Enough of this! Light the torches!

dialogues.speaker: CONVICT
dialogues.text: He tried to murder me! I should have been a dead man, if you hadn’t got here.

dialogues.speaker: MAGWITCH
dialogues.text: He lies! He’s a liar born and he’ll die a liar. Look at his face, his grovelling eyes. Look me in the eyes, villain. LOOK

dialogues.speaker: AT ME
dialogues.text: MAGWITCH makes another murderous lunge at his enemy, but is pulled back and down by four of the SOLDIERS. And it’s only then, forced to the floor like a wild animal, that MAGWITCH meets PIP’s eye, sees the fear and alarm on the young boy’s face. For a moment, MAGWITCH snarls, moves towards the boy - But PIP puts his hand to his own chest, and shakes his head. ‘It wasn’t me’ — A moment, then all the fight goes out of MAGWITCH. Something almost like shame comes to his face. And he allows himself to be hauled to his feet and manacled once more.  18 19 GREAT EXPECTATIONS (PAGES 10/12) 13.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Silhouetted against the low winter sun, the chained men and the soldiers march on. PIP and JOE bring up the rear, following the trail of burning tar. On the estuary, sinister shapes loom on the horizon -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The prison ships; menacing hulks, lifeless, ghost ships almost, lit by sulphurous torch-light. Two rowing boats await to take the convicts back to this hell. The second CONVICT is already on his way, his bloodied face full of fear. MAGWITCH is about to be led away too, but he turns a moment and, without looking at PIP, speaks to the SERGEANT.

dialogues.speaker: MAGWITCH
dialogues.text: I wish to say something. A man can’t starve. I took - stole - some wittles up at the village. A file too, and I'll tell you from where. The blacksmith’s. (Surprise from JOE, nothing from PIP) Brandy and a pie.

dialogues.speaker: SERGEANT
dialogues.text: Have you missed such an article as a pie, blacksmith?

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: My wife did.

dialogues.speaker: MAGWITCH
dialogues.text: So you're the blacksmith, are you? MAGWITCH steps towards JOE and PIP, causing the soldiers to stand. But JOE doesn’t flinch.

dialogues.speaker: MAGWITCH
dialogues.text: Then I’m sorry to say I’ve eat your pie.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: God knows you’re welcome to it. We don’t know what you've done, but we wouldn’t have you starve to death for it, would us Pip? MAGWITCH looks to PIP. PIP shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: MAGWITCH
dialogues.text: Pip.  20 GREAT EXPECTATIONS (PAGES 10/12) 14. The ghost of a smile, as he places the large manacled han on PIP’s head. A benediction. Then MAGWITCH is hauled away. Seated in the bow of the boat, manacled, hunched and filthy, MAGWITCH turns once more and steadily meets PIP’s eye as he is rowed off towards that wicked Noah's Ark. FADE TO BLACK.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Autumn now. Some time has passed, the marshes have lost some of their menace and the day is bright and clear as PIP lies in the long grass with JOE by his side, both concentrating hard on a slate, on which PIP chalks letter with intense concentration. JOE looks on in wonder;

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: I say, Pip old chap! What a scholar you are!

dialogues.speaker: PIP
dialogues.text: I should like to be, some day. Read it, Joe.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Read it. Read it.... He’s holding the slate upside down. PIP turns it and reads;

dialogues.speaker: PIP
dialogues.text: ‘Mi Deer JO i opE U R KRWITE WELL i shAL SOn B HabeLL 4 2 TEEDGE U JO an WOT LARX an BLeVE ME inFXN PIP’

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Why there’s a ‘J’! And an ‘0’, best ‘0’ I ever saw. Astonishing! How interesting reading is!

dialogues.speaker: PIP
dialogues.text: Perhaps I could teach you one day, Joe.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: P’raps. P’raps. Though I fear I am most awful, awful dull. Not like you, young scholar! When I think back to how small and flabby and scrawny you were when I first bought you to the forge -

dialogues.speaker: PIP
dialogues.text: Joe - please!  GREAT EXPECTATIONS (PAGES 10/12) 15.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: (a moment, then -) Ever the best of friends, ain’t us, Pip?

dialogues.speaker: PIP
dialogues.text: Ever the best of friends, Joe.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: And when you’s apprenticed to me - what larks. A bellow echoes across the marshes.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: She must be, what, two mile off? (PIP laughs) Best get us back then, old chap.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PIP’s head is ducked unceremoniously into a bucket of water.

dialogues.speaker: MRS JOE
dialogues.text: Now if this boy ain’t grateful, he never will be. (PIP comes up, gasping for air) I only hope he won’t be pampered.

dialogues.speaker: PUMBLECHOOK
dialogues.text: She ain’t in that line, mum, have no fear.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: ‘She’?

dialogues.speaker: MRS JOE
dialogues.text: Well, Miss Havisham ain’t a he, is she? Even you ain't as dull as that!

dialogues.speaker: PUMBLECHOOK
dialogues.text: Well put, ma’am. Good indeed. MRS JOE scrubs at PIP as if he were a stone floor. Soaped needed, towelled, thumped...  GREAT EXPECTATIONS (PAGES 10/12) 16. PIP is tugged and pulled into his best suit.

dialogues.speaker: MRS JOE
dialogues.text: Mr Pumblechook here -

dialogues.speaker: PUMBLECHOOK
dialogues.text: - her tenant, don’t you see.

dialogues.speaker: MRS JOE
dialogues.text: - goes to pay his rent and Miss ‘Avisham says does he know a boy who might go and play there for her pleasure and Mr Pumblechook, being always considerate and thoughtful of us -

dialogues.speaker: PUMBLECHOOK
dialogues.text: - no more than you deserve -

dialogues.speaker: MRS JOE
dialogues.text: - mentions this boy, prancing here. He’s to go straightaway! For all we know our fortune might be made and all he has to do is play!

dialogues.speaker: PIP
dialogues.text: But I don’t want to... The affect on MRS JOE is startling. She reddens, clutches at her heart.

dialogues.speaker: MRS JOE
dialogues.text: Listen to me, ungrateful wretch. D’you want to mix with people of quality and breeding, or stay here and rot with this great lumpen noodle?

dialogues.speaker: PIP
dialogues.text: Stay here?

dialogues.speaker: WHAT
dialogues.text: PIP looks to JOE, but there’s nothing he can do. PIP nods in acquiescence, and the pummelling continues.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PIP sits in PUMBLECHOOK’s cart, scrubbed and trussed up i his stiffest clothes, his suit too short.

dialogues.speaker: PUMBLECHOOK
dialogues.text: Eight times twelve?  GREAT EXPECTATIONS (PAGES 10/12) 17.

dialogues.speaker: PIP
dialogues.text: Ninety-six. Through twisted, overgrown parkland PIP sees the grim, dismal hulk of Satis House.

dialogues.speaker: PUMBLECHOOK
dialogues.text: Four times seventeen? Too slow! Sixty- eight. Nine times thirteen - PUMBLECHOOK keeps up his stream of questions as they step down from the cart and approach the gates, chained shut.

dialogues.speaker: PIP
dialogues.text: One hundred and seventeen -

dialogues.speaker: PUMBLECHOOK
dialogues.text: - minus thirty-two? Are you listening, boy? Boy? The garden of this once fine house is overgrown, the windows are either bricked up or barred, and from the outside it seems barely credible that the place could be inhabited. And yet...

dialogues.speaker: VOICE
dialogues.text: What name? A silhouette, calls from a window in a clear voice.

dialogues.speaker: PUMBLECHOOK
dialogues.text: Pumblechook!

dialogues.speaker: VOICE
dialogues.text: Quite right.

dialogues.speaker: PUMBLECHOOK
dialogues.text: Now, boy, remember your station and let your conduct be a credit unto those which brought you up by hand. And now a strikingly pretty young girl approaches, scarcely older than PIP but proud, self-assured, fearless - YOUNG ESTELLA. She regards PIP with a judgemental eye, then produces a large bunch of keys and opens the gate.

dialogues.speaker: ESTELLA
dialogues.text: Do you wish to see Miss Havisham?

dialogues.speaker: PUMBLECHOOK
dialogues.text: If Miss Havisham wishes to see me!  25 26 GREAT EXPECTATIONS (PAGES 10/12) 18.

dialogues.speaker: ESTELLA
dialogues.text: She don’t. (The gate is closed on PUMBLECHOOK. To PIP -) Come along. And with a glance back at the indignant, excluded PUMBLECHOOK, PIP follows her into the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The gloomy house is lit by a great many candles. ESTELLA takes one up and leads the way. Portraits and draped furniture can be glimpsed as they make their way up a fin staircase towards a door. They stop outside.

dialogues.speaker: ESTELLA
dialogues.text: Are you frightened?

dialogues.speaker: PIP
dialogues.text: I don’t know.

dialogues.speaker: ESTELLA
dialogues.text: Go in then.

dialogues.speaker: PIP
dialogues.text: After you, miss. ESTELLA smiles scornfully and walks away. PIP takes a breath and pushes the door open...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The room is lit with candles, with no glimpse of daylight It is the bedroom, and MISS ELEANOR HAVISHAM sits in fron of the mirror of her dressing table. She is quite the strangest lady he - or we - have ever seen. The wedding dress, the gloves, the veil are all decayed to a yellow-grey. The bride too has taken on this ashen, sickly taint.

dialogues.speaker: MISS HAVISHAM
dialogues.text: Come nearer. Let me look at you. PIP approaches gingerly, taking in more of the room; the stilled pendulum, the clock stopped at twenty to nine, th half-packed suitcase, the once-fine clothes now dusty and decayed.

dialogues.speaker: MISS HAVISHAM
dialogues.text: Look at me! (He does so) You are not afraid of a woman who has never seen the sun since you were born?  GREAT EXPECTATIONS (PAGES 10/12) 19.

dialogues.speaker: PIP
dialogues.text: No, ma’am.

dialogues.speaker: MISS HAVISHAM
dialogues.text: Then come closer. (her hand on her chest) Do you know what I touch here?

dialogues.speaker: PIP
dialogues.text: Your heart.

dialogues.speaker: MISS HAVISHAM
dialogues.text: Broken! The word is spoken with a weird pride.

dialogues.speaker: MISS HAVISHAM
dialogues.text: I sometimes have sick fancies and I have a sick fancy that I want to see some play. Play. Play! (PIP stands, frozen) Are you sullen and obstinate?

dialogues.speaker: PIP
dialogues.text: No, ma’‘am! I am very sorry for you and sorry that I can’t play. If you complain of me I will get into trouble with my sister, so I would play if I could, but it’s so new here.... She regards him. A moment. Very quiet.

dialogues.speaker: MISS HAVISHAM
dialogues.text: So new to him, so old to me, so melancholy. Call Estella! Estella! ESTELLA is already approaching, lit by candlelight. She walks past him and straight to MISS HAVISHAM. With a strange mechanical movement, a ritual almost, ESTELLA places her head on her lap. MISS HAVISHAM picks a broach from the dressing table and places it against ESTELLA’s dress, in her hair, watching how the jewels compliment her skin.

dialogues.speaker: MISS HAVISHAM
dialogues.text: Your own one day, my dear, and you will use it well. (she fixes the broach to ESTELLA, as if arming her) Now. Let me see you play cards with him.

dialogues.speaker: ESTELLA
dialogues.text: But he’s a common labouring boy.  GREAT EXPECTATIONS (PAGES 10/12) 20.

dialogues.speaker: MISS HAVISHAM
dialogues.text: Well? (whispered, for ESTELLA only) You can break his heart. They both look to PIP.

dialogues.speaker: ESTELLA
dialogues.text: What do you play, boy?

dialogues.speaker: PIP
dialogues.text: Nothing but beggar my neighbour, miss.

dialogues.speaker: MISS HAVISHAM
dialogues.text: So. Beggar him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The card game. MISS HAVISHAM looks on.

dialogues.speaker: PIP
dialogues.text: The jack of diamonds.

dialogues.speaker: ESTELLA
dialogues.text: ‘Jack’! He calls the knaves ‘jacks’, this boy. (MISS HAVISHAM smiles) And what coarse hands he has, and what thick boots. He’s nothing but a stupid, clumsy labouring boy. Humiliated, fighting back tears, PIP looks to MISS HAVISHAM.

dialogues.speaker: MISS HAVISHAM
dialogues.text: You say nothing of her. What do you think of her?

dialogues.speaker: PIP
dialogues.text: I don’t like to say.

dialogues.speaker: MISS HAVISHAM
dialogues.text: Whisper in my ear. And PIP approaches, until his face is close to MISS HAVISHAM - the yellow skin, the milky eyes.

dialogues.speaker: PIP
dialogues.text: I think she is very proud.

dialogues.speaker: MISS HAVISHAM
dialogues.text: Anything else.

dialogues.speaker: PIP
dialogues.text: I think she is very pretty.  28

dialogues.speaker: MISS HAVISHAM
dialogues.text: Anything else?

dialogues.speaker: PIP
dialogues.text: I think she is very insulting. I think I should like to go home.

dialogues.speaker: MISS HAVISHAM
dialogues.text: What? And never see her again? And PIP looks to ESTELLA. Beautiful. A whisper.

dialogues.speaker: PIP
dialogues.text: I think I’d like to see her again. MISS HAVISHAM smiles - she has won.

dialogues.speaker: MISS HAVISHAM
dialogues.text: Then you shall. But when, when shall I have you here again?

dialogues.speaker: PIP
dialogues.text: Today is Wednes...

dialogues.speaker: MISS HAVISHAM
dialogues.text: No Wednesdays, Thursdays, Fridays here, no days of the week, no weeks of the year. Come again after six days. Estella, take him down. Feed him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PIP waits in the yard of the derelict brewery as ESTELLA approaches. She carries a tray of bread, a mug of beer which she places on the floor in front of the boy. It's as if he were a dog in disgrace. The gesture is so hurtful and humiliating that tears start in Pip’s eye. YOUNG ESTELLA sees this. With an effort PIP struggles to retain his dignity. ESTELLA merely smiles and walks away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PIP’s slammed into the wall, MRS JOE hissing into his ear

dialogues.speaker: MRS JOE
dialogues.text: Did you disgrace yourself?

dialogues.speaker: PIP
dialogues.text: No -

dialogues.speaker: MRS JOE
dialogues.text: And did she pay you?  29 GREAT EXPECTATIONS (PAGES 10/12) 22.

dialogues.speaker: PIP
dialogues.text: No -

dialogues.speaker: MRS JOE
dialogues.text: Or say she’d do something for us, a reward?

dialogues.speaker: PIP
dialogues.text: She wants me to return -

dialogues.speaker: MRS JOE
dialogues.text: Then you will return, d’you hear me, you’1l return and play nicely until she sees us right. D’you understand? And she lets the shaken PIP go. JOE looks on, powerless.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A shower of sparks. PIP watches from his usual spot, taking in JOE’s thick boots, his coarse, dirty hands, the grime on his face as he hammers to the dirge-like song ‘Old Clem’. PIP holds up his own hands, examines them; the dirt under the scruffy nails. Suddenly, JOE breaks off singing.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Something wrong, old chap?

dialogues.speaker: PIP
dialogues.text: I wish you hadn’t taught me to call the knaves jacks.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: What’s that, Pip? PIP pauses for a moment. Then, in a rush -

dialogues.speaker: PIP
dialogues.text: And I wish my boots weren’t so thick and my hands weren't so coarse and I wish I wasn’t common! He tries to run but JOE stops him, scoops him up -

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Now, now old chap. That’s enough now, what's all this talk? ‘Common’? Who says you’s common? Tell me -

dialogues.speaker: PIP
dialogues.text: The girl, at Miss Havisham’s.  GREAT EXPECTATIONS (PAGES 10/12) 22a.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: But you aren’t common in the least, old boy! To my mind you are most uncommon. Uncommon small and an uncommon scholar...

dialogues.speaker: PIP
dialogues.text: I am ignorant and backward, Joe.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: And what of that letter you wrote, with the fine ‘J’ and the ‘0’, the most uncommon ‘O’ I ever saw...

dialogues.speaker: PIP
dialogues.text: I know nothing! You think much of me, that’s all.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: And ain't that something, old sport? Ain’t that something?

dialogues.speaker: OMITTED, INCORPORATED INTO 29 30
dialogues.text: 31 GREAT EXPECTATIONS (PAGES 10/12) 23.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PIP reads aloud from a scrappy Bible -

dialogues.speaker: PIP
dialogues.text: ‘,.and the Lord said unto Aaron ‘Thou and thy sons and thy father’s house.. An apple core hits him on the forehead. A classroom descending into anarchy. PIP looks to MRS WOPSLE, the ancient village teacher but she lies face down on her des snoring, entirely unaware of the chalk, conkers, shoes that fly through the air towards PIP - Rescue - BIDDY, MRS WOPSLE’s granddaughter, rushes in to calm the chaos.

dialogues.speaker: BIDDY
dialogues.text: Good gracious, what is going! Enough! Enough I say! BIDDY is barely eleven, scruffy, more plain than pretty, but with a humorous, pleasant, open face. An orphan, like PIP, who watches her closely now, with barely-concealed admiration.

dialogues.speaker: BIDDY
dialogues.text: Back to your desk, Pip. Very good. Now, let us read together - (the sleeping teacher) Quietly. ‘And the Lord said unto Aaron -  32 33 34 GREAT EXPECTATIONS (PAGES 10/12) 24. And while their teacher sleeps the class read aloud in a monotonous whisper. BIDDY catches PIP’s eye. She smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The class files out. BIDDY looks up. PIP is waiting there

dialogues.speaker: PIP
dialogues.text: I wonder if...you might teach me.

dialogues.speaker: BIDDY
dialogues.text: Teach you what, Pip?

dialogues.speaker: PIP
dialogues.text: Everything. I want to know everything.

dialogues.speaker: BIDDY
dialogues.text: (She laughs -) Everything? Goodness, well that might take a little time. Pip, whatever for? For THIS -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: YOUNG ESTELLA, austere and beautiful, opens the gate. Wordlessly, PIP follows. As they walk -

dialogues.speaker: ESTELLA
dialogues.text: Do you know the name of the house, boy? It is Satis House.

dialogues.speaker: PIP
dialogues.text: Is that...Greek?

dialogues.speaker: ESTELLA
dialogues.text: Greek or Latin or Hebrew or all three, for ‘enough’.

dialogues.speaker: PIP
dialogues.text: Enough House. That’s a curious name.

dialogues.speaker: ESTELLA
dialogues.text: Don’t loiter! It meant, when it was given, that whoever had this house, could want for nothing else...

dialogues.speaker: ESTELLA
dialogues.text: They must have been easily satisfied. The shabby remains of the HAVISHAM and POCKET families wait, and wait, and wait.  35 GREAT EXPECTATIONS (PAGES 10/12) 25. Three women, one man, shifty, unappealing, they regard PI as birds of prey might regard a sickly lamb.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH POCKET
dialogues.text: (to ESTELLA) Is this him? Is this the boy?

dialogues.speaker: ESTELLA
dialogues.text: (still walking) None of your business...

dialogues.speaker: COUSIN RAYMOND
dialogues.text: Well! Of all the...

dialogues.speaker: CAMILLA
dialogues.text: Will she see us today? We have been waiting!

dialogues.speaker: MRS RAYMOND
dialogues.text: Waiting all morning!

dialogues.speaker: SARAH POCKET
dialogues.text: We only wish to help! Smiling conspiratorially, ESTELLA whispers to PIP.

dialogues.speaker: ESTELLA
dialogues.text: Miss Havisham’s poor relations. She calls them her vultures. Ignore them. It drives them mad. PIP glances back at the glaring relatives and smiles. A sense of mischievous solidarity with ESTELLA -

dialogues.speaker: PIP
dialogues.text: And are they your relations too?

dialogues.speaker: ESTELLA
dialogues.text: Certainly not. I have no relations.

dialogues.speaker: PIP
dialogues.text: Then Miss Havisham is not your -

dialogues.speaker: ESTELLA
dialogues.text: (stops suddenly, turns) Well?

dialogues.speaker: PIP
dialogues.text: Well, miss?

dialogues.speaker: ESTELLA
dialogues.text: Am I pretty?

dialogues.speaker: PIP
dialogues.text: You are very pretty.  GREAT EXPECTATIONS (PAGES 10/12) 26.

dialogues.speaker: ESTELLA
dialogues.text: Am I insulting?

dialogues.speaker: PIP
dialogues.text: Not so much as last time, no. And ESTELLA slaps him, very hard. Pip gathers himself.

dialogues.speaker: ESTELLA
dialogues.text: Why don’t you cry?

dialogues.speaker: PIP
dialogues.text: (tearful, defiant) Because I don’t want to -

dialogues.speaker: ESTELLA
dialogues.text: You cried last time, I saw you -

dialogues.speaker: PIP
dialogues.text: - and I‘’ll never cry for you again. ESTELLA raises her hand to strike again

dialogues.speaker: JAGGERS
dialogues.text: Whom have we here? A large, well-dressed man - JAGGERS, MISS HAVISHAM’s solicitor. Powerful, immaculate, self-assured, he takes PIP’s chin in his large, manicured hand.

dialogues.speaker: JAGGERS
dialogues.text: This is the boy, is it? Well I have a pretty large experience of boys, and you're a bad set of fellows. Behave yourself. (to ESTELLA) He’s to wait in the ballroom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The door is closed on PIP. A fire has been lit in the great, grand ballroom, but the smoke hangs in the air lik Marsh mist. Rising out of it is the great, long banquet table, covered with dust and mould. In the centre of the room stands the clock, hands stopped at twenty to nine. Both repelled and fascinated by the sight, PIP moves towards the table’s centre-piece, a cake, now overhung with cobwebs and black with fungus. PIP peers closely, then recoils in disgust as a fat black beetle crawls from beneath the rotten icing. A voice -

dialogues.speaker: MISS HAVISHAM
dialogues.text: What do you think it is?  GREAT EXPECTATIONS (PAGES 10/12) 27.

dialogues.speaker: PIP
dialogues.text: A cake?

dialogues.speaker: MISS HAVISHAM
dialogues.text: A bride cake. Mine! Take my hand, walk with me. He does so, starting a slow steady circuit of the table.

dialogues.speaker: MISS HAVISHAM
dialogues.text: Today is my birthday -

dialogues.speaker: PIP
dialogues.text: Many happy ret-

dialogues.speaker: MISS HAVISHAM
dialogues.text: I will not have it spoken of! On this day of the year, long before you were born, this heap of decay- (- the cake - ) - was brought here and we have worn away together. Mice have gnawed at it and sharper teeth than mice have gnawed at me. When the ruin is complete, when they lay me dead in my bride’s dress on the bride’s table, the curse will be finished on him.

dialogues.speaker: PIP
dialogues.text: On who, Miss Havisham? But ESTELLA, the HAVISHAMS and POCKETS are waiting in the doorway.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH POCKET
dialogues.text: Miss Havisham. How well you look!

dialogues.speaker: MISS HAVISHAM
dialogues.text: (to PIP) Ah, the vultures. Estella - feed the boy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eating his lunch, a hunk of bread, PIP starts to explore the strange, overgrown gardens. - In a courtyard, a once fine coach stands derelict, a remnant of another era. - The stables, empty and sinister. - A once elegant greenhouse, twisted and shattered. - Rows and rows of barrels, the source of the Havisham fortune, now broken and drained. There’s someone there.  GREAT EXPECTATIONS (PAGES 10/12) 28. - YOUNG ESTELLA, stood still, holding her face up to the warmth of the sun, eyes closed. A private reverie. PIP hides, watches - - as now ESTELLA skips from barrel to barrel, singing quietly to herself. Youthful, natural, exuberant, not at all the stern and harsh girl we have seen before now. PIP watches, sinking deeper into love, when -

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG GENTLEMAN
dialogues.text: Who are you? PIP turns. A PALE YOUNG GENTLEMAN, his own age, lanky and puny.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG GENTLEMAN
dialogues.text: Who let you in? Who gave you leave to prowl about?

dialogues.speaker: PIP
dialogues.text: Estella.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG GENTLEMAN
dialogues.text: Estella? That witch! And now we see ESTELLA’s p.o.v, watching unseen.

dialogues.speaker: PIP
dialogues.text: Take that back!

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG GENTLEMAN
dialogues.text: I will not!

dialogues.speaker: PIP
dialogues.text: You will take that back.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG GENTLEMAN
dialogues.text: Fight me then. (and he starts to take off his jacket) Regular rules. Come to the ground! And he starts to prance like some absurd prize-fighter. I her hiding place, ESTELLA stifles her laughter. PIP, too, isn’t quite sure what to do until a feeble jab lands on his arm, and he responds with a neat punch to th pale YOUNG GENTLEMAN’s nose. It’s as much fluke as skill, but he’s surprised to see the boy sprawling on the floor. The boy takes the blow in very good spirits, dabbing at his nosebleed, springing to his feet.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG GENTLEMAN
dialogues.text: That means you won. Honour is satisfied. Much obliged. Good afternoon!  38 39 GREAT EXPECTATIONS (PAGES 10/12) 29. And pulling on his jacket, the ridiculous YOUNG GENTLEMAN strides off. ESTELLA watches this all, her cheeks flush, exhilarated.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PIP is shown to the gate once more.

dialogues.speaker: ESTELLA
dialogues.text: You are to return the day after tomorrow at noon and alternate days after that. Expect no reward. As she turns the key, ESTELLA pauses.

dialogues.speaker: ESTELLA
dialogues.text: You may kiss me. If you like.

dialogues.speaker: PIP
dialogues.text: What for? She simply smiles and offers her cheek. PIP kisses it. A moment of pure bliss and utter confusion And then he is somehow out of the gate, watching ESTELLA walk away. CLOSE on ESTELLA; her private smile -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: - and then on BIDDY, smiling indulgently as PIP struggles

dialogues.speaker: PIP
dialogues.text: ...-Henry II, Richard I. King John? Henry III, Richard the...?

dialogues.speaker: BIDDY
dialogues.text: Edward I, II and III, Richard II, Henry -

dialogues.speaker: PIP
dialogues.text: How do you manage it, Biddy?

dialogues.speaker: BIDDY
dialogues.text: Manage what?

dialogues.speaker: PIP
dialogues.text: To know so much.

dialogues.speaker: BIDDY
dialogues.text: I suppose I catch it. Like a cough. They laugh. A moment, as PIP plucks up courage.  40 4l 42 GREAT EXPECTATIONS (PAGES 10/12) 30.

dialogues.speaker: PIP
dialogues.text: May I tell you a secret?

dialogues.speaker: BIDDY
dialogues.text: I suppose you may.

dialogues.speaker: PIP
dialogues.text: I don’t want to be a blacksmith. I want to be a gentleman.

dialogues.speaker: BIDDY
dialogues.text: Oh I wouldn’t if I was you. Aren't you fond of the forge? And Joe?

dialogues.speaker: PIP
dialogues.text: Yes...

dialogues.speaker: BIDDY
dialogues.text: Then don’t you think you’d be happier as you are?

dialogues.speaker: PIP
dialogues.text: I have a particular reason.

dialogues.speaker: BIDDY
dialogues.text: To do with a certain young lady I suppose. Your princess. (PIP says nothing) And do you want to be a gentleman to win her? Or to spite her? PIP takes this in; the truth is he’s not sure.

dialogues.speaker: BIDDY
dialogues.text: Once again: Henry III -

dialogues.speaker: PIP
dialogues.text: Edward I, II and III, Richard II, Henry IV... Music up. The wheeze of a harmonium -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PIP scrubs at his hands, in an attempt to get the filth off. Wincing, he scrubs and scrubs until the skin is pink and raw.  43 44 GREAT EXPECTATIONS (PAGES 10/12) 31.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PIP’s gentleman-hands are pushing a wheelchair as he sing ‘Old Clem’. MISS HAVISHAM sings along in a quavering voice, as if singing in her sleep.

dialogues.speaker: ESTELLA, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Once there was a certain gentleman, very handsome he was, and Miss Havisham loved him and hoped to marry him. And he deserted her -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Music plays on an old music-box. ESTELLA is teaching an awkward, clumsy PIP to dance -

dialogues.speaker: PIP
dialogues.text: But why?

dialogues.speaker: ESTELLA
dialogues.text: Because he was a man of course. This was before I was born. You are out-of-time. Listen -

dialogues.speaker: PIP
dialogues.text: So what do you remember?

dialogues.speaker: ESTELLA
dialogues.text: I remember nothing. Nothing before Miss Havisham. 1-2-3, 1-2-3

dialogues.speaker: PIP
dialogues.text: So is your name Havisham?

dialogues.speaker: ESTELLA
dialogues.text: Of course, what other name might it be? You ask a great many questions. I don’t ask you about your parents -

dialogues.speaker: PIP
dialogues.text: My parents are dead. They died when I was a child. ESTELLA hesitates, just for a moment.

dialogues.speaker: ESTELLA
dialogues.text: Then we are both orphans. And that is all we have in common. Suddenly -

dialogues.speaker: MISS HAVISHAM
dialogues.text: Estella! PIP and ESTELLA start guiltily.  45 46 47 48 GREAT EXPECTATIONS (PAGES 10/12) 32.

dialogues.speaker: MISS HAVISHAM
dialogues.text: What are you doing?

dialogues.speaker: ESTELLA
dialogues.text: (stepping away from him) Teaching Pip to dance. Like a gentleman. MISS HAVISHAM takes this in.

dialogues.speaker: MISS HAVISHAM
dialogues.text: You are growing tall, Pip. Bring the blacksmith to see me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JOE, absurd in his Sunday Best, looks in the mirror, lick his hand and smooths down a stubborn tuft of hair as ESTELLA leads PIP and JOE towards MISS HAVISHAM’s room. PIP holds JOE’s hand, reassuringly. But as they reach the door, he drops it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Imperious, MISS HAVISHAM surveys the Blacksmith who, in his anxiety and confusion, insists on addressing all his answers to PIP. ESTELLA watches, amused.

dialogues.speaker: MISS HAVISHAM
dialogues.text: You are the husband of the sister of the boy?

dialogues.speaker: JOE PIP
dialogues.text: Being that I hup and Just say yes, Joe. Just married your sister, by ‘yes’. Yes, Miss Havisham. which I meantersay -

dialogues.speaker: MISS HAVISHAM
dialogues.text: And you have reared the boy with the intention of making him your apprentice?

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: You know, Pip, as you and I ever were the best of friends, and it were look for’ard to betwixt us as being calculated to lead to larks - PIP looks to ESTELLA, and is mortified to see her laughin at JOE.  GREAT EXPECTATIONS (PAGES 10/12) 33.

dialogues.speaker: MISS HAVISHAM
dialogues.text: The boy has made no objection to the trade?

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Larks being the great wish of your heart, Pip -

dialogues.speaker: MISS HAVISHAM
dialogues.text: Enough! Estella - (she looks up) Bring me that purse. Reluctantly, ESTELLA does so.

dialogues.speaker: MISS HAVISHAM
dialogues.text: Pip has earnt a premium here. Here are five and twenty guineas. Give it to your new master, Pip. You are now a blacksmith. Goodbye. PIP is mortified; this is not a reward, it’s a punishment He looks to ESTELLA, who is no longer laughing -—

dialogues.speaker: MISS HAVISHAM
dialogues.text: You are not ashamed of being a blacksmith?

dialogues.speaker: PIP
dialogues.text: No, but...

dialogues.speaker: MISS HAVISHAM
dialogues.text: Then you are a blacksmith. Goodbye. PIP stands, frozen. He had thought his place was here. No he must leave. A final plea...

dialogues.speaker: PIP
dialogues.text: But...but am I to come again?

dialogues.speaker: MISS HAVISHAM
dialogues.text: (a moment, then) No. Goodbye Pip. You have been a good boy. Estella, show him out. Goodbye, goodbye.... PIP looks to ESTELLA.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The gate clangs shut for the last time. Thrown out of paradise, PIP is devastated.

dialogues.speaker: PIP
dialogues.text: Perhaps we shall meet again. One day? ESTELLA is struggling to maintain her cold demeanour. But  51 52 53 GREAT EXPECTATIONS (PAGES 10/12) 34.

dialogues.speaker: ESTELLA
dialogues.text: It seems unlikely. And with this she turns and, holding the lamp aloft, walk away. C.U. on ESTELLA - her private sadness. JOE holds out his hand. A moment of hesitation, then PIP takes it and walks off into the darkness.

dialogues.speaker: FADE TO BLACK
dialogues.text: The sound of hammering, the roar of a furnace. CAPTION. TEN YEARS LATER...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The noise, sweat and soot of the forge. Face and hands black from the smoke, the ADULT PIP hammers at the red ho iron. Nineteen now, he has grown into a fine, handsome young man; dark-featured, strong, determined.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JOE works nearby, well into middle-age now, but still retaining his child-like gaucheness. He and PIP eat a makeshift lunch, tearing at bread with sooty hands. There’s a figure in the doorway; ADULT BIDDY, now in her early twenties, carrying a pile of books. More womanly, a little neater, but with the same pleasant, open face.

dialogues.speaker: PIP
dialogues.text: Joe, may I?... JOE nods assent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PIP and BIDDY run full pelt across the marshes. A beautiful summer's day.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pip and Biddy read. But Biddy’s eyes are not on the page. Instead she is plucking up courage. Her hand reaches across and takes Pip’s hand (or perhaps even a kiss?) Either way, awkwardness has set in.

dialogues.speaker: PIP
dialogues.text: Biddy, I wish -  54 55 GREAT EXPECTATIONS (PAGES 10/12) 35.

dialogues.speaker: BIDDY
dialogues.text: Go on...Pip?

dialogues.speaker: PIP
dialogues.text: I wish...I wish I could fall in love with you.

dialogues.speaker: BIDDY
dialogues.text: Oh.

dialogues.speaker: PIP
dialogues.text: Can I say this to you?

dialogues.speaker: BIDDY
dialogues.text: Don’t mind me.

dialogues.speaker: PIP
dialogues.text: I wish that I could love you and my work and settle down with Joe at the forge, and that we could all be sitting here together, three completely different people. I wish that I could be content, but...

dialogues.speaker: BIDDY
dialogues.text: You cannot.

dialogues.speaker: PIP
dialogues.text: ("No") Might you be content with me?

dialogues.speaker: BIDDY
dialogues.text: I might. But then I’m easily pleased. A smile. Pip takes her hand, but in consolation now.

dialogues.speaker: BIDDY
dialogues.text: Do you think of her very often?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The house remains unchanged. Illicit, a trespasser, PIP loiters at the chained gate, hoping for a glimpse of a face at the window. No sign of life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PIP hammering again, venting all his frustration on the iron. JOE arrives, anxious and stiff; frightened almost.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Gentleman to see you, Pip.  56 GREAT EXPECTATIONS (PAGES 10/12) 36. A figure steps out of the shadows. A large, well-dressed man with a dark complexion, a face from the past. MISS HAVISHAM’s solicitor. JAGGERS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JAGGERS seems incongruous and uneasy in the humble kitchen.

dialogues.speaker: JAGGERS
dialogues.text: You are Phillip Pirrip, commonly known as Pip, am I right?

dialogues.speaker: PIP
dialogues.text: Yes, sir.

dialogues.speaker: JAGGERS
dialogues.text: And this is your brother-in-law, Joseph, or ‘Joe’ Gargery.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: I am that man.

dialogues.speaker: JAGGERS
dialogues.text: Your wife, Mr Gargery?

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Dead, sir. Bad heart. Passed away this five years, sir, while on the rampage and I miss her every -

dialogues.speaker: JAGGERS
dialogues.text: Condolences. My name is Jaggers and I am a lawyer in London. I am pretty well known. I have unusual business to transact with you and I commence by explaining that it is not of my originating. If my advice had been asked, I would not be here. It was not asked, and you see me here. Do you understand? (Nothing from PIP and JOE) Joseph Gargery, I am the bearer of an offer to relieve you of this young fellow your apprentice. I am here to inform you that he has great expectations! (PIP and JOE uncomprehending. ) He has come into a handsome fortune, and it is the desire of the present possessor of this fortune that he be removed from his present circumstances and brought up as a gentleman in London. PIP, his heart beating fast, turns to JOE.  GREAT EXPECTATIONS (PAGES 10/12) 37.

dialogues.speaker: JAGGERS
dialogues.text: Now. Do you have any objections?

dialogues.speaker: PIP
dialogues.text: No...no, I don’t think so...

dialogues.speaker: JAGGERS
dialogues.text: There are, of course, conditions. The first is that you always retain the name of Pip. You have no objection I daresay.

dialogues.speaker: PIP
dialogues.text: I...have no objection.

dialogues.speaker: JAGGERS
dialogues.text: The second stipulation is that the name of the liberal benefactor remains a profound secret until the person chooses to reveal it. You most positively prohibited from making any enquiry on this question. Do you understand?

dialogues.speaker: PIP
dialogues.text: I understand.

dialogues.speaker: JAGGERS
dialogues.text: Mr Gargery? Throughout the above, JOE has gone into a sort of trance.

dialogues.speaker: JAGGERS
dialogues.text: Mr Gargery, this is for you. (A purse - ) Twenty guineas. As compensation. For the loss of his services. He drops the money on the table. JOE stares at it.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: If you think money can make compensation for the loss of the little orphan what come to the forge and was ever the best of friends...

dialogues.speaker: JAGGERS
dialogues.text: Yes, the sentiment is touching, now do you want the money or no - And JOE is standing suddenly, fist raised, red-faced.

dialogues.speaker: JOE PIP
dialogues.text: If you’re a man, come on! Enough, Joe! Please, enough Bull-baiting and badgering - me in my own home. Well come on! Come on I say! And JOE sits back down. Gingerly, JAGGERS returns the money to his pocket.  57 58 GREAT EXPECTATIONS (PAGES 10/12) 38.

dialogues.speaker: INT/EXT. GARGERY HOUSE
dialogues.text: PIP escorts JAGGERS from the house.

dialogues.speaker: JAGGERS
dialogues.text: Well Mr Pip, I think the sooner you leave here the better. Shall we say one week?

dialogues.speaker: PIP
dialogues.text: And what will I do in London?

dialogues.speaker: JAGGERS
dialogues.text: ‘Do’?

dialogues.speaker: PIP
dialogues.text: What will be my trade, my profession?

dialogues.speaker: JAGGERS
dialogues.text: A gentleman. You will be a gentleman. (He offers his hand -) You will please consider me your guardian now. PIP takes JAGGERS’ manicured hand. JOE watches from the doorway. He sees the handshake. INT. TAILOR’S SHOP - DAY 58 PUMBLECHOOK sits in his chair, eating a buttered roll, even more red-faced, complacent and maddening than before

dialogues.speaker: PUMBLECHOOK
dialogues.text: Seven times sixteen, your answer please -

dialogues.speaker: PIP
dialogues.text: Mister Pumblechook.

dialogues.speaker: PUMBLECHOOK
dialogues.text: Too slow, too slow -—

dialogues.speaker: PIP
dialogues.text: Mr Pumblechook, I have some news... JUMP CUT -— Bustle and fuss. A roll of fabric is unveiled, and anothe and another as PUMBLECHOOK, unctuously sycophantic now, talks PIP through his finest linen.

dialogues.speaker: JAGGERS, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: You will need some new clothes - not working clothes. And you will want some money - shall we say twenty guineas?  59 60 61 62 63 GREAT EXPECTATIONS (PAGES 10/12) 39.

dialogues.speaker: PUMBLECHOOK
dialogues.text: May I? Now this is number 4, a very sweet article for light summer-wear, really top notch and extra super. May I? Feel the knap? D’you feel it? How it catches the light? Extra super fine and quite in vogue amongst London gentry. Now, number 5. PIP is measured, fussed and fidgeted over by PUMBLECHOOK.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BIDDY and JOE wait for an unveiling, an expectant audience. Gentleman PIP enters, transformed and slightly absurd. Th country tailoring is a poor imitation of already-dated fashions, but he does his best to smile. BIDDY smiles. JOE has only one word.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Astonishing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An awkward last supper. PIP sits and eats, uncomfortable in his finery, and watches as JOE swabs his plate with a hunk of bread. Later, PIP takes BIDDY to one side.

dialogues.speaker: PIP
dialogues.text: Can I ask you, Biddy, to help Joe on a little? (She doesn’t understand) In his learning, and his manners.

dialogues.speaker: BIDDY
dialogues.text: Oh, won't his manners do then?

dialogues.speaker: PIP
dialogues.text: (JOE licks his fingers - ) They do very well here.  64 65

dialogues.speaker: BIDDY
dialogues.text: Oh, they do very well here, do they?

dialogues.speaker: PIP
dialogues.text: But if, when, I choose to bring Joe into a higher sphere, they will hardly do him justice -

dialogues.speaker: BIDDY
dialogues.text: And don’t you think he knows that? (PIP is taken aback) Have you never considered that he may be proud?

dialogues.speaker: PIP
dialogues.text: Proud?

dialogues.speaker: BIDDY
dialogues.text: Yes, proud, too proud to let anyone take him out of a place that he is competent to fill and fills well and with respect - I thought you knew this! I thought you of all people would know him best of all! And BIDDY walks off briskly, leaving a pensive PIP. JOE has been watching. He smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Late that night. JOE sits in front of the fire as PIP, dressed in his old clothes, stands behind him and cuts hi hair. A scene that has taken place many times before, but anxious now, JOE frightened almost. Until -

dialogues.speaker: PIP
dialogues.text: You know I shall never forget you, Joe.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Ever the best of friends, old chap. JOE lays his hands on PIP’s. And they lapse into silence once more.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And now it’s time to say goodbye. PIP is walking away, when he feels something hit him in the back. He turns to look - a shoe, thrown by JOE.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Sorry! It was meant for luck.

dialogues.speaker: GREAT EXPECTATIONS, (PAGES 10/12)
dialogues.text: Another shoe comes flying - BIDDY’s now. And another, all of them laughing, as PIP dodges the hail of shoes, turns and leaves. As BIDDY cries, JOE comforts her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PIP stands at the gates of Satis House, practicing his lines, his elocution.

dialogues.speaker: PIP
dialogues.text: Miss Havisham I wished to say..Good afternoon, Miss Havisham, I wondered if I might... A figure approaches with a lamp; MISS SARAH POCKET, one o the vultures. She regards him with undisguised contempt.

dialogues.speaker: SARAH POCKET
dialogues.text: What do you want?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MISS HAVISHAM sits at her dressing-table, as before, but older, frailer, more decayed. Around her, waiting on her word, are the vultures - CAMILLA POCKET, COUSIN RAYMOND, MRS RAYMOND, their faces grim and resentful. SARAH POCKET shows PIP in.

dialogues.speaker: MISS HAVISHAM
dialogues.text: Pip! Pip! Come join us. How handsome you look in your finery. Come closer! (with malicious relish) You remember my cousin Sarah Pocket. She works for me now. I employ her. SARAH scowls, takes her place amongst the POCKETS.

dialogues.speaker: PIP
dialogues.text: (choosing his words) I came to take my leave of you, Miss Havisham -

dialogues.speaker: MISS HAVISHAM
dialogues.text: Yes, I have seen Mr Jaggers, I know all about it. You are adopted by a mysterious benefactor?

dialogues.speaker: PIP
dialogues.text: Yes, Miss Havisham.

dialogues.speaker: MISS HAVISHAM
dialogues.text: How mysterious! Who could it be? But isn’t that wonderful news, everyone! The POCKETS, the vultures, are speechless with rage, but powerless. MISS HAVISHAM is positively gleeful.  66 67 68 GREAT EXPECTATIONS (PAGES 10/12) 42.

dialogues.speaker: MISS HAVISHAM
dialogues.text: Go now. All of you, go - (the POCKETS file past the usurper, glaring. The two of them now -) She's abroad, Pip, educating for a lady, far out of reach; prettier than ever; admired by all who see her. Do you feel that you have lost her? Be patient, Pip. I’m sure your paths will cross.

dialogues.speaker: PIP
dialogues.text: I hope so. (taking her hand) Miss Havisham, I wished to say how grateful I am for -

dialogues.speaker: MISS HAVISHAM
dialogues.text: Hush now, Pip. You will always keep the name of Pip, you know. (JAGGERS’ words exactly. She returns to her mirror) Goodbye, Pip. Goodbye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And we are plunged straight into the heat and filth of th meat market on a summer morning; no scenic view, no splendour, just the noise and bustle of a working city. Clutching JAGGERS’ address in one hand, a carpet bag in the other, PIP alights from his coach and is immediately overwhelmed by the clamour and chaos. EXT. JAGGERS’ OFFICES, SMITHFIELD - DAY 67 PIP staggers to the door of JAGGERS’s office, an unprepossessing ramshackle affair. He forces his way through a crowd at the door; a shabby, desperate lot, all awaiting the lawyer’s return. INT. JAGGERS’ OFFICES, SMITHFIELD - DAY 68 Two ghastly black plaster heads sit on a high mantelpiece A clerk stands on a chair, dusting them. Short, pock- marked, square-faced, this is MR WEMMICK.

dialogues.speaker: WEMMICK
dialogues.text: Mr Jaggers'1ll be with you shortly, Mr Pip. He’s at the Bailey, getting evidence together.  GREAT EXPECTATIONS (PAGES 10/12) 43.

dialogues.speaker: PIP
dialogues.text: (The heads-) Whose likenesses are they?

dialogues.speaker: WEMMICK
dialogues.text: ‘Likenesses’? This is their true selves! Casts made in Newgate, fresh from the gallows. Murderer, and a forger of wills. Very crafty in particular, this one but the evidence was too strong. (To the death mask) Not so crafty now are you, my friend? (WEMMICK steps down off the chair, shows PIP a ring on his finger) This was his too. Made a gift of it to me, just before the end. And with a shudder, PIP notices that WEMMICK wears a number of similar rings; dead mens’ jewellery, two handfuls of it.

dialogues.speaker: WEMMICK
dialogues.text: Not worth much, but they’re portable, and they’re property. That’s my guiding star, Mr Pip; get hold of portable property. (a bustle at the door) That’s Mr Jaggers now. And sure enough, JAGGERS bursts into the room, surrounded by an extraordinary gaggle of clients and suitors. Even a he addresses PIP he keeps up a running dialogue with the desperate clients, who swarm around him, bees around a hive. (The following at great speed, italics addressed to PIP, the rest thrown out into the hubbub, like crumbs to pigeons.)

dialogues.speaker: JAGGERS
dialogues.text: Now I have nothing to say to YOU, and I want to know no more than I know - Good- day Mr Pip - and as for you, it’s a toss- up, I told you it was a toss-up, have you paid Mr Wemmick? Yes or no? Yes? Good. Now let go of my coat! - I trust your journey was satisfactory, Mr Pip - One more word from YOU and I will throw in the case, do you hear? ‘Feelings’? Who spoke of ‘feelings’? We’ll have no ‘feelings’ here - follow me, Mr Pip, please - not another word, not one, or I will drop the case, now let go of my coat and get out of my way. Follow me please, Mr Pip! This way -  69 70 71 72

dialogues.speaker: GREAT EXPECTATIONS, (PAGES 10/12)
dialogues.text: INT. JAGGERS’ OFFICE, SMITHFIELD - CONTINUOUS And the office door slams and they are in the relative calm of JAGGERS’ private room.

dialogues.speaker: JAGGERS
dialogues.text: You’ve met Mr Wemmick. He keeps the money, so no doubt you will see a great deal of him. Good gracious, is that your new suit? Here - (Business cards -) Tailor, hatter, hosier, bootmaker, you'll find your credit good with all of them. (A purse -) Here is your allowance, I trust you will find it generous. As he speaks, JAGGERS pours hot water into a washbasin; JAGGERS washes his hands and neck, washing away the work with perfumed soap.

dialogues.speaker: JAGGERS
dialogues.text: Your temporary lodgings are at Barnard’s Inn, near here so that I might keep an eye on you and pull you up when I find you going wrong. You will go wrong, Mr Pip, but that’s no fault of mine. EXT. BARNARD’S INN - DAY PIP stands outside the ramshackle boarding house, accommodation for single gentlemen.

dialogues.speaker: JAGGERS, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: You will be lodging with Mr Herbert Pocket, Miss Havisham’s great nephew... INT. STAIRWELL, BARNARD’S INN - DAY PIP climbs the ramshackle staircase, unimpressed.

dialogues.speaker: JAGGERS, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Mr Pocket is a clerk. He has no expectations, but will ensure that you can hold your own with gentlemen of quality. A note on the door reads ‘Return Shortly!’ INT. CHAMBERS, BARNARD’S INN - DAY 44. 69 70 rented 71 72 PIP looks out of a sooty window at a murky view of London A bustle behind him, and HERBERT POCKET is there, young, lanky, pale, laden down with parcels of food.  73 GREAT EXPECTATIONS (PAGES 10/12) 45.

dialogues.speaker: HERBERT
dialogues.text: Mr Pip?

dialogues.speaker: PIP
dialogues.text: Mr Pocket?

dialogues.speaker: HERBERT
dialogues.text: I am extremely sorry, but I thought, coming from the country you might like a little fruit. Strawberries! (a red pulpy mess) Strawberry jam! Have you seen your lodgings? It is by no means splendid, but I’m sure we shan’t come to blows... He stops in his tracks, stares at PIP, then raises his fists and assumes an absurd boxing stance.

dialogues.speaker: HERBERT
dialogues.text: Put them up! Come on, come on... Is he mad perhaps?

dialogues.speaker: PIP
dialogues.text: I beg your pardon?

dialogues.speaker: HERBERT
dialogues.text: Take your ground! Regular rules apply! And PIP remembers too.

dialogues.speaker: HERBERT
dialogues.text: The prowling boy!

dialogues.speaker: PIP
dialogues.text: The pale young gentleman! INT. CHAMBERS, BARNARD’S INN - DAY 73 SERVING BOYS lay out a meal in the small, comfortable drawing room - a kind of early take-away. Wine is poured and HERBERT tells his story =

dialogues.speaker: HERBERT
dialogues.text: I was there with my Aunt Sarah on a trial visit. Miss Havisham fancied that she wanted to ‘see me play’. Clearly she didn’t take a fancy to me. Poor taste on her part but just as well, otherwise I might have been what-d’you-called-it to Estella. (PIP leans in) Affianced. Betrothed. Engaged. But it was not to be.

dialogues.speaker: PIP
dialogues.text: I’m very sorry.  GREAT EXPECTATIONS (PAGES 10/12) 46.

dialogues.speaker: HERBERT
dialogues.text: Sorry? The girl’s a Tartar, hard and haughty and capricious to the last degree, brought up by Miss Havisham to wreak revenge on all the male sex.

dialogues.speaker: PIP
dialogues.text: Why should she wreak revenge?

dialogues.speaker: HERBERT
dialogues.text: Lord, Mr Pip, don’t you know?

dialogues.speaker: PIP
dialogues.text: Please - tell me. INT. CHAMBERS, BARNARD’S INN - NIGHT 74 A little later. PIP and HERBERT are eating now.

dialogues.speaker: HERBERT
dialogues.text: Miss Havisham was very rich and very proud, a spoilt child. Her mother died when she was young, and her father married again, his cook would you believe, and they had a boy, Arthur, who was - how might I put this? - not entirely legitimate and consequently nursed a terrible grudge..At this point I might break off and mention that in London it is not the custom to put the knife into the mouth, for fear of accidents- (PIP removes the knife) Also the spoon is not generally used over- hand, but under. Do you mind?

dialogues.speaker: PIP
dialogues.text: Not at all. I am grateful.

dialogues.speaker: HERBERT
dialogues.text: Now, Miss Havisham met a certain man and loved this man devotedly, passionately, idolised him, and soon they were engaged. He persuaded her to buy her half- brother's share in the brewery at an immense price, so that when he was her husband he could hold and manage it all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A wedding cake. Extravagant, ornate, it stands at the centre of a long banquet table in an elegant, light-fille room.

dialogues.speaker: HERBERT, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Well, the happy day arrived -  76 77 78 GREAT EXPECTATIONS (PAGES 10/12) 47. SERVANTS buzz around the table in preparation for the wedding feast. Life, activity everywhere.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the fine master bedroom, MISS ELEANOR HAVISHAM sits in front of a mirror. It’s hard to see her face beneath the veil, but she’s a little older than one might expect for bride in the last years of the 18th Century. Nevertheless there’s no mistaking the grace and beauty there - - nor the discontent and resentment in the eyes of ARTHUR HAVISHAM, the half-brother, sulky and malign.

dialogues.speaker: HERBERT, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: The wedding dresses were brought, the wedding tour planned out...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A letter, sealed with crimson wax is held in the hand of an UNSEEN MESSENGER —

dialogues.speaker: HERBERT, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: ...the wedding guests were invited, my parents among them, the feast laid out, a great bride-cake made. We follow the UNSEEN FIGURE as he passes the great banquet, heading through the bustle of preparations

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A clock reads twenty to nine. THE UNSEEN MESSENGER gingerly approaches the family wedding group.

dialogues.speaker: HERBERT, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: The groom wrote her a letter... ARTHUR HAVISHAM beckons to him, takes the letter from the MESSENGER and regards it carefully. A moment of hesitation, of conscience. Then a decision -—

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR HAVISHAM
dialogues.text: Sister - (ELEANOR HAVISHAM turns) It’s for you. Smiling, trustingly, she takes the letter. ARTHUR’s eyes fix on her face as she breaks the crimson seal. The room falls silent. She scans the letter. Scans it again, trying to make sense of the words. The letter fall from her hands -  79

dialogues.speaker: 79A
dialogues.text: 80 81 82 83 GREAT EXPECTATIONS (PAGES 10/12) 48. Reeling, she stumbles backwards into the dressing table. Jars of powder, jewels fall to the floor. ARTHUR looks on in horror and shame.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The SERVANTS hear a terrible cry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The wedding veil masks ELEANOR’s haunted face as she walk the corridors of the great house.

dialogues.speaker: HERBERT, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: She received the letter -

dialogues.speaker: PIP, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: - when she was dressing for marriage -

dialogues.speaker: PIP/HERBERT, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: - at twenty minutes to nine. A hand clad in white wedding-lace reaches into a great clock and stops the pendulum. The time is turned back to twenty to nine - The wooden shutters on the high windows are closed agains the summer evening light, the great curtains are drawn - On the table, the glorious wedding-cake - A small figure in white retreats into the darkness of the house. The doors slam shut. INT. CHAMBERS, BARNARD’S INN - NIGHT 80

dialogues.speaker: HERBERT
dialogues.text: It was a conspiracy between the groom and her brother to defraud Miss Havisham and break her heart. And in that they most surely succeeded. (a moment) Let’s step out, get some fresh air shall we?

dialogues.speaker: OMITTED 84
dialogues.text: INT. TAVERN — NIGHT 85 PIP and HERBERT, drunk and companionable now, are squeeze into the corner of a smoky Smithfield tavern.

dialogues.speaker: HERBERT
dialogues.text: Trade - that’s where the money is. In the future I shall trade to Egypt for silks and spices, Ceylon for elephant’s tusks -

dialogues.speaker: PIP
dialogues.text: But for now?

dialogues.speaker: HERBERT
dialogues.text: For now I am a clerk. In a counting house, with a sweetheart whom I can’t afford to marry.

dialogues.speaker: PIP
dialogues.text: Is there profit in being a clerk?

dialogues.speaker: HERBERT
dialogues.text: None whatsoever. Not a penny. EXT. BARNARD’S INN - NIGHT 86 PIP and HERBERT stumble home, pretty drunk now.

dialogues.speaker: HERBERT
dialogues.text: But you look about you, you know? That’s the grand thing. You go to work every day, and look about you and one day you see your opening and you swoop! (his arm around PIP) You know. I don’t much care for ‘Mr Pip’. I tell you what I should like. Seeing as we are so harmonious, and you have been a blacksmith, would you mind ‘Handel’ for a familiar name? (PIP doesn’t get it) The Harmonious Blacksmith? It’s by Handel? (he sings a phrase) Do you mind?

dialogues.speaker: PIP
dialogues.text: I would like it very much. And arm-in-arm, woozy with ale, they stagger on.  87

dialogues.speaker: 87A
dialogues.text: 88 GREAT EXPECTATIONS (PAGES 10/12) 50.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hungover, PIP looks on as WEMMICK unlocks the cash-box. JAGGERS is there, with a told-you-so look.

dialogues.speaker: JAGGERS
dialogues.text: Back so soon! Very good, very good. Now I’ve taken the liberty of enrolling you in a gentleman’s club...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The headquarters of -

dialogues.speaker: JAGGERS, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: The Finches of the Grove. It’s quite the thing, apparently, for gentlemen of distinction.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A dining room, heavy with cigar smoke, packed with drunken, bellicose young men in evening dress.

dialogues.speaker: STARTOP
dialogues.text: As Bullfinch of this Grove, and in the most honoured name of Chaffinch -

dialogues.speaker: THE FINCHES
dialogues.text: Fringillae!

dialogues.speaker: STARTOP
dialogues.text: Goldfinch -

dialogues.speaker: THE FINCHES
dialogues.text: Carduelis!

dialogues.speaker: STARTOP
dialogues.text: - and Hawfinch!

dialogues.speaker: THE FINCHES
dialogues.text: Coccothraustes!

dialogues.speaker: STARTOP
dialogues.text: - may the present promotion of good feeling ever reign predominant among the noble finches of the Grove! Gentlemen -

dialogues.speaker: THE FINCHES
dialogues.text: Huzzah! Huzzah! For the Finches of the Grove. Glasses are raised and dashed down. On PIP and HERBERT, bemused. Later, cigars are savoured. PIP coughs, HERBERT whispers  GREAT EXPECTATIONS (PAGES 10/12) 51.

dialogues.speaker: HERBERT
dialogues.text: Hold the smoke in your mouth. PIP does so, coughs again. HERBERT pats his back. All of this is observed by one of the other Finches, BENTLEY DRUMMLE.

dialogues.speaker: PIP
dialogues.text: And how do I sound? (putting on a voice) Should I speak like this?

dialogues.speaker: HERBERT
dialogues.text: Just be yourself.

dialogues.speaker: PIP
dialogues.text: The one thing I can’t be is myself. And now they are joined by STARTOP and BENTLEY DRUMMLE.

dialogues.speaker: STARTOP
dialogues.text: Pip, isn’t it? Pip -

dialogues.speaker: PIP
dialogues.text: Pirrip.

dialogues.speaker: STARTOP
dialogues.text: Pirrip. Pip Pirrip. How remarkable. And where are your people from?

dialogues.speaker: PIP
dialogues.text: ‘My people’?

dialogues.speaker: HERBERT
dialogues.text: From Kent. They’re the Kentish Pirrips.

dialogues.speaker: DRUMMLE
dialogues.text: You sound like some sort of apple. DRUMMLE is big-boned, sulky, an arrogant young baronet. H regards PIP with barely concealed contempt, speaking in a sluggish, fat-tongued drawl.

dialogues.speaker: DRUMMLE
dialogues.text: So what school did you go to, Kentish Pirrip?

dialogues.speaker: PIP
dialogues.text: Well. I was..educated..independently by a French governess. Mademoiselle...just ‘Mademoiselle’. A puff of the cigar. Silence

dialogues.speaker: STARTOP
dialogues.text: So. How about some games? STARTOP and DRUMMLE head off.  89 90 91 92

dialogues.speaker: 92A
dialogues.text: 93 GREAT EXPECTATIONS (PAGES 10/12) 52.

dialogues.speaker: HERBERT
dialogues.text: ‘Mademoiselle’? And they collapse into appalled laughter. And -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anarchy now, as the room is demolished in a mad, violent, brawling game, a version of the Eton wall-game. Bread flies through the air, wine sloshes onto clothes and carpet as SERVANTS look on in horror. Bullingdon-style high-jinks. Instinctively, PIP can’t help but tidy-up a little. DRUMMLE watches...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HERBERT approaches, a young woman on his arm; small, pretty, a little fierce.

dialogues.speaker: HERBERT
dialogues.text: Handel, this is Clara. My beloved fiancee. Aren’t I the lucky one?

dialogues.speaker: CLARA
dialogues.text: Herbert, please -

dialogues.speaker: PIP
dialogues.text: So pleased to meet you. Shall we - And they enter... INT. MAYFAIR APARTMENT — DAY 93 Empty rooms, high-ceilinged and refined, a far cry from Barnards Inn. PIP, HERBERT and CLARA look around. HERBERT seems a little wary, but PIP’s mind is made up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 94 GREAT EXPECTATIONS (PAGES 10/12) 53.

dialogues.speaker: PIP
dialogues.text: What do you think? It would be at my expense, of course. HERBERT looks to CLARA, warily.

dialogues.speaker: CLARA
dialogues.text: You’re a clerk, Herbert Pocket. CLARA sighs, and bustles out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But PIP has had his way, and they’ve moved in now, half- unpacked, a temporary feel. A private house-warming. Two BARLEY SISTERS are there, CLARA’s giggling cousins, a pair of teenage POCKET BOYS, pair of POCKET GIRLS, one of whom is tuning up a fiddle. PIP and HERBERT are rolling up the carpet -

dialogues.speaker: HERBERT
dialogues.text: She’s a fierce little thing, I can’t deny it, but what can I do? I love her, Handel, and we can’t choose whom we love.

dialogues.speaker: PIP
dialogues.text: No, we can’t.

dialogues.speaker: HERBERT
dialogues.text: The thing is to marry her, but you can’t Marry, not while you’re looking about you. As soon as I have my capital...

dialogues.speaker: CLARA
dialogues.text: Gentlemen! Are we ready? JUMP CUT TO - A dance, a mad galop, HERBERT and the SISTERS watching admiringly, as PIP and CLARA charge from one end of the room to the other. One of the POCKET GIRLS plays the fiddle as accompaniment.

dialogues.speaker: HERBERT
dialogues.text: Goodness, Pip, whoever taught you to dance? And PIP, woozy and drunk, remembers. HERBERT cuts in, sweeps CLARA away.

dialogues.speaker: CLARA
