dialogues.text: No, no more, please - my feet! PIP takes a glass of wine, drains it, staggers, hurls the glass into the fireplace.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WEMMICK opens the cash-box once more. 54. 95 96 97 98

dialogues.speaker: JAGGERS
dialogues.text: I'd like to meet these extravagant Finches of yours.

dialogues.speaker: PIP
dialogues.text: But why?

dialogues.speaker: JAGGERS
dialogues.text: Tomorrow evening, no ceremony, no dinner dress. Shall we say six o’clock? Wemmick, pay him the money. And JAGGERS is gone. WEMMICK counts out the money.

dialogues.speaker: PIP
dialogues.text: What should I make of him, Mr Wemmick?

dialogues.speaker: WEMMICK
dialogues.text: He’s a deep one. Deep as Australia. Don’t take it personal Mr Pip. It’s professional. Only professional. (taking pity) And if tonight you have nothing better to do, I wonder if you wouldn’t mind coming home with me to Walworth. I’ve not much to show you but there’s a garden, a summer house, one or two curiosities -—

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WEMMICK and PIP walk together to the village of Walworth, a mean, muddy little suburb along the Old Kent Road.

dialogues.speaker: WEMMICK
dialogues.text: I know what you’re thinking. It’s like living in the country! (PIP smiles politely) Now, here we are —  100 101 GREAT EXPECTATIONS (PAGES 10/12) 55. And now they stand before the strangest house - a small cottage amongst gardens and ditches, unremarkable in ever respect except that castle’s crenelations have been added to the roof, the windows given fake Gothic frames, a flagstaff and miniature moat added. The result is absurd, but homely too.

dialogues.speaker: WEMMICK
dialogues.text: That’s a real flagstaff, and on Sunday I run up a real flag. My own doing. Looks pretty, don’t it? Winding a handle, a miniature drawbridge descends.

dialogues.speaker: WEMMICK
dialogues.text: Now let me introduce you to the Aged P. INT. WEMMICK’S PARLOUR - DAY 100 In a chair sits a very elderly, very deaf, shrunken old man, grinning away as WEMMICK nods vigorously at him.

dialogues.speaker: WEMMICK
dialogues.text: Well, Aged Parent, how are you?

dialogues.speaker: AGED P
dialogues.text: Alright John, all right.

dialogues.speaker: WEMMICK
dialogues.text: This is Mr Pip, Aged P, not that you can hear a word I’m saying. Nod away at him Mr Pip if you don’t mind. Nod and wink, nod...and nod...keep nodding...one more.. (as PIP nods, he checks his fob watch) Nearly time, Aged P! Keep noddin, I'1l heat the poker. EXT. ROOF, WEMMICK’S HOUSE - DAY 101 WEMMICK stands - with watch in one hand and red-hot poker in the other - at a small calibre cannon which sits on th wooden battlements.

dialogues.speaker: WEMMICK
dialogues.text: Mr Pip, if you’d care to do the honours? BANG! The house shakes, the AGED grins and wriggles with glee.

dialogues.speaker: WEMMICK
dialogues.text: Now. Who wants some salad?  GREAT EXPECTATIONS (PAGES 10/12) 56. 102 INT. WEMMICK’S PARLOUR - DAY 102 They sit down for a simple, pleasant supper.

dialogues.speaker: WEMMICK
dialogues.text: I’m my own plumber, my own gardener, my own carpenter, it’s all mine. We’re as proud of it as Punch, isn’t that right, Aged?

dialogues.speaker: AGED P
dialogues.text: All right, John my boy, very good.

dialogues.speaker: PIP
dialogues.text: Does Mr Jaggers admire it?

dialogues.speaker: WEMMICK
dialogues.text: Never seen it, never heard of it, never seen the Aged, never heard of him. When I come into The Castle I leave Mr Jaggers behind and if it’s not in any way disagreeable, you'll oblige me by doing the same.

dialogues.speaker: PIP
dialogues.text: Of course. I quite understand.

dialogues.speaker: WEMMICK
dialogues.text: Though I will give you one piece of advice, Mr Pip. When you dine with Mr Jaggers tomorrow, look at his housekeeper.

dialogues.speaker: PIP
dialogues.text: His housekeeper? Why?

dialogues.speaker: WEMMICK
dialogues.text: I’ll say no more here, not here. But mark my words - look at his housekeeper, and see a wild beast tamed. 103 INT. DINING ROOM, JAGGERS’ HOUSE, GERRARD STREET - NI MOLLY THE HOUSE-KEEPER stands sentinel in the corner of the room, impervious to the chatter of the Finches. PIP i fascinated by MOLLY, watching her intently. Tall, lithe, nimble, early-forties, there’s something compelling about her, something familiar. The Finches complete their absurd ceremony.

dialogues.speaker: STARTOP
dialogues.text: - may the present promotion of good feeling ever reign predominant among the noble finches of the Grove! Gentlemen -  104 GREAT EXPECTATIONS (PAGES 10/12) 57.

dialogues.speaker: THE FINCHES
dialogues.text: Huzzah! Huzzah! For the Finches of the Grove. Throughout this, DRUMMLE sneers and rolls his eyes, and JAGGERS sees him do so.

dialogues.speaker: JAGGERS
dialogues.text: Pip, tell me, who’s the spider? Blotchy, sprawly, sulky fellow. BENTLEY DRUMMLE lounges on a chair alone, examining JAGGERS’ glassware with a snobbish eye.

dialogues.speaker: PIP
dialogues.text: That's Bentley Drummle. The richest young man in England.

dialogues.speaker: JAGGERS
dialogues.text: Is he now?

dialogues.speaker: PIP
dialogues.text: Owns most of Derbyshire apparently.

dialogues.speaker: JAGGERS
dialogues.text: Bentley Drummle, is it? Very promising. JAGGERS crosses to DRUMMLE, and PIP looks back to MOLLY. Suddenly she returns his gaze; a challenge, startlingly ferocious. Disturbed, PIP looks away. INT. DINING ROOM, JAGGERS’ HOUSE, GERRARD STREET - NIGHT The young men are seated, drunk, boorish and loud, thier sleeves rolled-up as PIP takes on DRUMMLE in arm- wrestling. PIP, unsurprisingly, wins.

dialogues.speaker: DRUMMLE
dialogues.text: A fluke. Pure chance.

dialogues.speaker: STARTOP
dialogues.text: Come, come, Bentley, concede defeat, Pip beat you fair and square.

dialogues.speaker: THE FINCHES
dialogues.text: Admit it, Drummle!/Fair’s fair.

dialogues.speaker: DRUMMLE
dialogues.text: I was under the impression that the Finches was a club for gentlemen. I can't be expected to compete against country boys. A tense silence. HERBERT places a placatory hand on PIP’s ‘Don’t rise to it’...  GREAT EXPECTATIONS (PAGES 10/12) 58.

dialogues.speaker: PIP
dialogues.text: What do you mean, Mr Drummle?

dialogues.speaker: DRUMMLE
dialogues.text: No slight, I assure you. In fact I salute you, Kentish Pirrip! (raising his glass) You have the arms of a blacksmith! PIP looks to JAGGERS, impassive and blank, then stands suddenly. DRUMMLE stands too, ready for a fight, but JAGGERS places a hand on his forearm.

dialogues.speaker: JAGGERS
dialogues.text: You talk of strength. If you want to see strength, look at this - MOLLY is serving behind him. In a flash, JAGGERS grabs he wrists like the snap of a trap. MOLLY flinches, tries to twist away —

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: Master, don’t!

dialogues.speaker: JAGGERS
dialogues.text: Molly, let them see your wrists!

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: Master! Please -

dialogues.speaker: JAGGERS
dialogues.text: Both your wrists. Show them, Molly. Come! And with resignation, MOLLY obediently shows first one, then the other wrist to the table.

dialogues.speaker: JAGGERS
dialogues.text: There’s power there. Very few men have the power this woman has. Both are horribly scarred; old, deep scars, scratches in the flesh. The bold young men recoil, but MOLLY turns her eyes defiantly on them, one-by-one.

dialogues.speaker: JAGGERS
dialogues.text: That'll do, Molly. You have been admired, and can go. The room is shocked into silence.

dialogues.speaker: JAGGERS
dialogues.text: Gentleman, I’d like to propose a toast. Mr Drummle, I drink to you! Surprised and flattered, BENTLEY smirks. PIP scowls. The toast is drunk.  105 106 107 GREAT EXPECTATIONS (PAGES 10/12) 59. INT. DRESSING ROOM, JAGGERS’ HOUSE - NIGHT 105 MOLLY delivers the bowl for JAGGERS to wash his hands. A little woozy, PIP stands in the doorway.

dialogues.speaker: PIP
dialogues.text: I apologise, if anything disagreeable...

dialogues.speaker: JAGGERS
dialogues.text: Pooh! It’s nothing, Pip. I like that Spider though.

dialogues.speaker: PIP
dialogues.text: Do you? I don’t.

dialogues.speaker: JAGGERS
dialogues.text: No, quite right. Don’t have anything to do with him. Keep as clear of him as you can. But I do like the fellow, Pip. He has great promise. Why, if I was a fortune-teller... (He catches PIP’s eye) But I am not a fortune teller. You know what I am, don’t you? Goodnight Pip. And, disquieted, PIP heads off. EXT. JAGGER’S HOUSE - NIGHT 106 PIP is leaving when he becomes aware of a presence. MOLLY stands on the street.

dialogues.speaker: JAGGERS
dialogues.text: Molly! JAGGERS is in the doorway. MOLLY lowers her head, and follows him up. The ringing of a bell -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The bell continues, persistent and shrill, then the sound of voices. Violently hungover, a bottle by his bed, PIP struggles into consciousness, and sees his newly-acquired Manservant PEPPER - impertinent, fourteen years-old - slouching in the doorway.

dialogues.speaker: PIP
dialogues.text: Pepper, I’ve told you, I’m not to be woken unless...

dialogues.speaker: PEPPER
dialogues.text: Someone to see you, sir.  108 GREAT EXPECTATIONS (PAGES 10/12) 60. And awkward, trussed up in his Sunday best, JOE enters.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: How are you, Pip? INT. LIVING ROOM, MAYFAIR APARTMENTS — DAY 108 Clutching some sort of iron contraption, JOE struggles to take in the grandeur of the bachelor apartments, while PI pulls on his clothes and conceals the empty bottles.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: I have brought you a toasting fork as a gift, for crumpets and the like - (brandishing the ugly contraption - ) - but it seems you have no need.

dialogues.speaker: PIP
dialogues.text: (taking it politely) It’s perfect, Joe. Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: PEPPER
dialogues.text: Tea or coffee, sir?

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: (shaking PEPPER’s hand) Tea, sir, if you don’t mind. Coffee, I find a little...powerful. (With an insubordinate smirk, PEPPER goes.) Us two being now alone, Sir...

dialogues.speaker: PIP
dialogues.text: ‘Sir’? Joe, how can you call me ‘sir’? There’s an unfortunate lack of patience in PIP’s voice.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Us two being now alone, I might tell you my purpose for being here in the abode of a gentlemen, which is that I ‘ave had communication from a certain Miss A.

dialogues.speaker: PIP
dialogues.text: Miss A?

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Miss ‘Avisham. She wishes to see you, Sir, on a matter of great import. PIP takes this in. HERBERT enters, tidying himself up.

dialogues.speaker: PIP
dialogues.text: Joe, this is my good friend Herbert Pocket.  109 GREAT EXPECTATIONS (PAGES 10/12) 61.

dialogues.speaker: HERBERT
dialogues.text: (more manic hand-shaking) Mr Gargery, I’ve heard a great deal about you.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: (flattered) You have? But what is there to say?

dialogues.speaker: PIP
dialogues.text: A very great deal. Suppose we have a celebration?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PIP, HERBERT and a mystified JOE enter. Not a restaurant exactly, but a fashionable eating house; noisy, bustling.

dialogues.speaker: PIP
dialogues.text: The finest place in London. The pressed duck is superb. (WAITERS descend) They know us here... A WAITER takes hold of JOE’s hat and coat. JOE holds on tight, as if being robbed. PIP places a hand on JOE’s arm JOE lets go... Jump cut. WAITERS set dishes. JOE tucks the napkin in to his shirt collar as the others lay it on their laps.

dialogues.speaker: HERBERT
dialogues.text: How do you find London, Mr Gargery?

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: London! London - what a place! What a place! ‘Course, I wouldn’t keep a pig in it myself... JOE stares helplessly at the array of cutlery. PIP indicates discreetly which spoon to use. HERBERT notices PIP passing on the lesson. JUMP CUT to later. JOE, a little drunk and garrulous now, is mopping up his gravy with a hunk of bread, as PIP look on, uncomfortable.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: -..and Biddy’s ever right and ready, a teacher now, and a fine one too. She sends her regards to you...

dialogues.speaker: HERBERT
dialogues.text: Mr Gargery - more wine? JOE pauses to empty from his glass. Before PIP knows what he’s saying -  GREAT EXPECTATIONS (PAGES 10/12) 62.

dialogues.speaker: PIP
dialogues.text: Joe, there’s really no need to be so conscientious in emptying your glass. The rim should never touch your nose, Joe. And JOE lowers the glass, and attempts a smile. PIP is mortified, but it’s too late. The damage is done.

dialogues.speaker: HERBERT
dialogues.text: Gentlemen, if you’1l excuse me... Sensing the discomfort, he leaves. A silence, then -

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: (With false brightness ) Well, business concluded, I’11l be off! Flustered, he reaches into his pocket for his purse.

dialogues.speaker: PIP
dialogues.text: You are going now?

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Yes I am.

dialogues.speaker: PIP
dialogues.text: Put your money away, Joe.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: No, I insist..

dialogues.speaker: PIP
dialogues.text: You won't stay the night?

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: No, I will not. (sorting through coins) Now, I have five bob here...

dialogues.speaker: PIP
dialogues.text: For God’s sake, put your money away! His voice is too loud. People are staring. A terrible moment, as JOE puts his money away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PIP follows JOE out into the street.

dialogues.speaker: PIP
dialogues.text: At least let me walk you to the coach -

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: I‘1ll find my way.  112 GREAT EXPECTATIONS (PAGES 10/12) 63.

dialogues.speaker: PIP
dialogues.text: But we have barely spoken, Joe! I wished to show you some sights - JOE turns. With great dignity.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Pip, dear old chap, life is made of ever so many partings welded together. Divisions must come and be met as they come. If there’s been any fault today, it’s mine...

dialogues.speaker: PIP
dialogues.text: No, Joe, it’s...

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: You and me is not two figures to be together in London. It ain’t that I’m proud, but that I want things to be right, and you shall see me no more in these clothes. I’m wrong in these clothes, I’m wrong out of the forge, the kitchen or the marshes. Come sometime and put your head in at the forge window and see Joe the blacksmith, and what larks we shall have! But here, Pip, here I am most awful dull. (as he goes) God bless you, dear old Pip, old chap. God bless you! And he walks away, into the crowd. PIP stands, stricken with guilt and regret as the crowd swallows him up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The matter still hangs heavy with PIP the next day as he approaches SATIS HOUSE A figure approaches - MISS SARAH POCKET, still grim-faced with contempt. She opens the door -

dialogues.speaker: SARAH POCKET
dialogues.text: You know the way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MISS HAVISHAM is in her usual place at the dressing table

dialogues.speaker: MISS HAVISHAM
dialogues.text: Come in, Pip! How do you do, Pip! You kiss my hand as if I was a queen, eh?

dialogues.speaker: PIP
dialogues.text: You wished to see me?  113 GREAT EXPECTATIONS (PAGES 10/12) 64. But MISS HAVISHAM is staring over his shoulder, gesturing with her eyes. PIP follows her gaze, and sees; Out of the darkness steps ESTELLA, all grown-up now. Startlingly beautiful and womanly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The gardens are little changed since PIP and ESTELLA played there as children.

dialogues.speaker: ESTELLA
dialogues.text: I am to be sent to London. I am to go on show - myself and the jewels.

dialogues.speaker: PIP
dialogues.text: Do you wish to go on show?

dialogues.speaker: ESTELLA
dialogues.text: Why ask? We have no choice, you and I, but to obey instructions. They are at the old brewery; the site of YOUNG PIP and HERBERT’s fight all those years ago. ESTELLA steps across the barrels - an echo of the past. For a moment, some of that old girlishness returns.

dialogues.speaker: ESTELLA
dialogues.text: I watched you, you know. That day, fighting for my honour. I must have been a strange little creature to hide and watch, but I did. I enjoyed it very much.

dialogues.speaker: PIP
dialogues.text: You rewarded me very much.

dialogues.speaker: ESTELLA
dialogues.text: Did I?

dialogues.speaker: PIP
dialogues.text: You kissed me. She regards him for a moment. Not unkindly;

dialogues.speaker: ESTELLA
dialogues.text: Poor Pip. You imagine yourself a young knight from a child’s story, tearing away the cobwebs and thorns, letting in the sunshine. Marrying the princess. But you must know, Pip -— (a confidence) - I have no heart.

dialogues.speaker: PIP
dialogues.text: I don’t believe it. How can there be beauty without a heart?  114 GREAT EXPECTATIONS (PAGES 10/12) 65.

dialogues.speaker: ESTELLA
dialogues.text: Oh, I have a heart to be stabbed in or shot in, and if it ceased to beat I should cease to be. (she takes his hand, places it over her heart) But I have no softness there, no sympathy. Sentiment. Nonsense. I’ve been made that way. (PIP is about to speak) I am serious, Pip. If we’re to be thrown together you must believe me. For both our sakes.

dialogues.speaker: PIP
dialogues.text: I’m sorry, I cannot. I will not.

dialogues.speaker: ESTELLA
dialogues.text: (A moment. ) Very well. It is said at any rate. Come, Miss Havisham will be expecting you at your old post. And she walks towards the house, PIP following on, his eyes fixed on her extraordinary beauty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MISS HAVISHAM whispers in PIP’s ear. A voice -

dialogues.speaker: MISS HAVISHAM
dialogues.text: Is she beautiful, graceful, well-grown? Do you admire her?

dialogues.speaker: PIP
dialogues.text: Of course.

dialogues.speaker: MISS HAVISHAM
dialogues.text: Then love her, love her, Pip. If she favours you, love her, if she wounds you, love her, if she tears your heart to pieces - as it gets older, it will tear deeper - love her, love her, love her... (her arm is round his neck, pulling him in -) I adopted her to be loved, bred her, educated her, developed her into what she is that she might be loved. You know what love is, Pip? Blind devotion, self- humiliation, degradation, utter submission, giving up your heart and soul to the smiter as I did to that man...

dialogues.speaker: JAGGERS
dialogues.text: Miss Havisham!

dialogues.speaker: GREAT EXPECTATIONS, (PAGES 10/12)
dialogues.text: The lawyer stands in the doorway, ESTELLA a little behind him, breathless, disturbed.

dialogues.speaker: JAGGERS
dialogues.text: That is enough excitement for one day. Pip, you are requested to escort Estella to London tomorrow morning. I suggest an early night. Miss Havisham, shall we take a trip? Once round? And JAGGERS begins to push MISS HAVISHAM on one of her circuits of the wedding banquet. PIP and ESTELLA share on last look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PIP approaches the forge. He must apologise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: JOE is back, hard at work, his back to the door. PIP watches for a moment. About to speak - But what could he possibly say? Unseen, he slips away without a word. EXT. COUNTRY LANE -— DAWN 117 Next morning, and their carriage hurtles towards London. In her furred travelling dress, ESTELLA is more beautiful than ever, and as PIP drinks her in, she leans out of the window, feeling the sun and breeze on her face. Exhilaration, an escape -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ESTELLA’s luggage is unloaded at the door of the fine house of her chaperone, MRS BRANDLEY and her daughter MIS BRANDLEY.

dialogues.speaker: ESTELLA
dialogues.text: Mrs Brandley is to be paid a large sum of money to introduce me to society. The jewels and I. We are to be shown to people and people are to be shown to us.

dialogues.speaker: PIP
dialogues.text: May I come and see you?  GREAT EXPECTATIONS (PAGES 10/12) 67.

dialogues.speaker: ESTELLA
dialogues.text: Of course. Miss Havisham expects it.

dialogues.speaker: PIP
dialogues.text: And may I kiss you again? She thinks a moment. Then steps back and, in the shadow o the coach, offers up her cheek. PIP kisses her, then searches her face for some response. Impassive, emotionless. Nothing.

dialogues.speaker: ESTELLA
dialogues.text: Goodbye, Pip.

dialogues.speaker: PIP
dialogues.text: I love her, Herbert. I adore her. PIP and HERBERT, a little drunk and sentimental.

dialogues.speaker: HERBERT
dialogues.text: You've always adored her. You brought your adoration and your luggage here together.

dialogues.speaker: PIP
dialogues.text: If I adored her then, I adore her twice as much now.

dialogues.speaker: HERBERT
dialogues.text: Lucky for you then, that you’re picked out for her. (PIP looks to him) How can it be otherwise? (A deep breath -) May I say something, Handel? Something disagreeable. Are you ready? One-two- three...forget her! Detach yourself from her. Think of her upbringing and of Miss Havisham, know that she will never change and only misery can come of loving her. Forget Estella.

dialogues.speaker: PIP
dialogues.text: I can’t.

dialogues.speaker: HERBERT
dialogues.text: You can’t try?

dialogues.speaker: PIP
dialogues.text: It's impossible.

dialogues.speaker: HERBERT
dialogues.text: Well then. Another drink?.  120 121

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hungover, PIP looks on as WEMMICK unlocks the cash-box once more.

dialogues.speaker: JAGGERS
dialogues.text: I see bills from vintners, bills from jewellers, bookmakers. I expected you to go wrong, Mr Pip, but really you're excelling yourself.

dialogues.speaker: PIP
dialogues.text: I’1l endeavour to show more restraint -

dialogues.speaker: JAGGERS
dialogues.text: Do as you will, it is no business of mine. Wemmick, give Mr Pip the money he requires. Now if you’ll excuse me... And he heads off to his office. As he opens the door, PIP glimpses a figure; BENTLEY DRUMMLE. JAGGERS shakes his hand warmly. DRUMMLE catches PIP’s eye - an insolent grin The door is closed on PIP -

dialogues.speaker: OMITTED 121B
dialogues.text: 122 GREAT EXPECTATIONS (PAGES 10/12) 69.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Slopping wine glasses clash together. A dining room, heav with cigar smoke, packed with drunken, bellicose young me in evening dress.

dialogues.speaker: THE FINCHES
dialogues.text: Huzzah! Huzzah! For the Finches of the Grove!

dialogues.speaker: STARTOP
dialogues.text: And the ladies that they sigh for! Rowdy jeers and leers. PIP, lost in drink, is barely listening. DRUMMLE watches, stands coolly, eyes on PIP.

dialogues.speaker: DRUMMLE
dialogues.text: I would like to raise a glass to a lady of my acquaintance, a lady of Richmond, a peerless beauty, Miss Estella Havisham!

dialogues.speaker: THE FINCHES
dialogues.text: Miss Estella Havisham! PIP wakes up, struggles to his feet.

dialogues.speaker: PIP
dialogues.text: I know that lady -

dialogues.speaker: DRUMMLE
dialogues.text: Do you? Oh, Lord!

dialogues.speaker: PIP
dialogues.text: - and you know nothing of her.

dialogues.speaker: DRUMMLE
dialogues.text: On the contrary, I’ve had the pleasure of dancing with her. Several times -

dialogues.speaker: PIP
dialogues.text: You lie! Consternation from the fellow Finches.

dialogues.speaker: HERBERT
dialogues.text: Steady now, Handel.

dialogues.speaker: DRUMMLE
dialogues.text: Indeed. Then perhaps you might care to follow me. And with a scrape of chairs the Finches rise and follow DRUMMLE, through dining room doors...  123 124 GREAT EXPECTATIONS (PAGES 10/12) 70.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Spoiling for a fight, the Finches storm down the staircas into -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A grand society ball is in full swing. The room is packed with young London’s brightest and finest. But none is mor striking, more beautiful and startling than ESTELLA. She stands amidst a pack of love-lorn suitors; handsome, high-society men. The FINCHES storm in and, sensing trouble, the crowd parts. ESTELLA catches swaggering DRUMMLE’s eye, and offers up a radiant smile. Then she sees PIP. Their eyes lock, and for a fleeting moment, there’s a loo of startling sadness and regret in ESTELLA’s eyes - Then it is gone, and once again she is beautiful, cold, invulnerable. She takes DRUMMLE’s hand.

dialogues.speaker: DRUMMLE
dialogues.text: A waltz! The music begins, and ESTELLA and DRUMMLE start to dance. All this is observed by JAGGERS, dispassionately observin the resolution of a plan. PIP can take no more. Devastated, he flees. ESTELLA spots this, stops dancing abruptly and goes to follow - - but DRUMMLE’s meaty hand grasps her bare arm.

dialogues.speaker: DRUMMLE
dialogues.text: The dance is not yet over. The other DANCERS see this confrontation.

dialogues.speaker: ESTELLA
dialogues.text: Remove your hand, sir. Their eyes lock - a challenge. ESTELLA is unflinching. DRUMMLE concedes. ESTELLA departs, leaving her would-be lover standing alone, humiliated. JAGGERS, watching, smiles.

dialogues.speaker: OMITTED, INCORPORATED INTO SC. 123. 124
dialogues.text: 125 GREAT EXPECTATIONS (PAGES 10/12) 71.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A verandah overlooks the Thames. Alone, PIP contemplates the view and his own misery, when;

dialogues.speaker: ESTELLA
dialogues.text: Oh, Pip, Pip. Will you never take warning? He turns. Bejewelled, silhouetted in the doorway in her ball-gown, she looks more beautiful than ever before.

dialogues.speaker: PIP
dialogues.text: How can you do it, Estella?

dialogues.speaker: ESTELLA
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: PIP
dialogues.text: Give your affections to that man.

dialogues.speaker: ESTELLA
dialogues.text: All sorts of ugly creatures hover about a lighted candle. Can the candle help it?

dialogues.speaker: PIP
dialogues.text: No, but you can.

dialogues.speaker: ESTELLA
dialogues.text: Perhaps. If I cared.

dialogues.speaker: PIP
dialogues.text: But you must care! To encourage a man as despised, as addle-headed and unworthy and boorish as Bentley Drummle, a man who has nothing to recommend him except money...

dialogues.speaker: ESTELLA
dialogues.text: Pip, don’t let it affect you so.

dialogues.speaker: PIP
dialogues.text: I can’t help it! To give that man the looks and smiles you never give to me...

dialogues.speaker: ESTELLA
dialogues.text: Do you want me to deceive you?

dialogues.speaker: PIP
dialogues.text: Do you deceive him?

dialogues.speaker: ESTELLA
dialogues.text: Yes! Yes, him and many, many other men. I deceive all of them but you.

dialogues.speaker: PIP
dialogues.text: Then why am I to be spared?  126 127 128 GREAT EXPECTATIONS (PAGES 10/12) 72.

dialogues.speaker: ESTELLA
dialogues.text: Oh, Pip. Why do you think? A moment. The music from the ballroom can still be heard and, without speaking, ESTELLA crosses to PIP and takes his hand. Nervously, PIP places his other hand on ESTELLA’s waist. A breathless, intimate moment, their faces close as they dance. Then a voice -

dialogues.speaker: JAGGERS
dialogues.text: Lovely evening, isn’t it? A storm later. So they say. Estella - Mr Drummle requires your presence. (ESTELLA hesitates) Urgently. (she leaves) You should hurry home, Pip.

dialogues.speaker: PIP
dialogues.text: I thought...I was led to believe...

dialogues.speaker: JAGGERS
dialogues.text: Dangerous to presume anything, Pip. And he leaves PIP in his agony. Over the Thames, a crackl of thunder...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PIP hurries home from the ball. It’s a wild, wet and stormy night, and it’s all PIP can do to unlock the door and stumble into the apartment building.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PIP enters his rooms, and hesitates -—

dialogues.speaker: PIP
dialogues.text: Herbert? You’re back early! Hello? A noise from the stairs. PIP heads back -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PIP peers down the stairwell, as a CLOAKED FIGURE hurries downwards into the darkness -

dialogues.speaker: PIP
dialogues.text: Hello! Hello, who’s there? No reply. He turns, returns to his apartment and -  GREAT EXPECTATIONS (PAGES 10/12) 72A.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: - in an echo of the graveyard scene, a figure LOOMS UP behind PIP, step towards him, arms outstretched. PIP shouts out -  GREAT EXPECTATIONS (PAGES 10/12) 73. PIP (CONT’D) MAGWITCH Who are you?! What are I startled you! you...

dialogues.speaker: PIP MAGWITCH
dialogues.text: What do you want?! How did Forgive me, Master, I you get in here? didn’t mean to startle you.

dialogues.speaker: GET AWAY FROM ME
dialogues.text: PIP looks to the door, and MAGWITCH braces himself, dangerous now -

dialogues.speaker: MAGWITCH
dialogues.text: Who’s there?

dialogues.speaker: PIP
dialogues.text: No-one.

dialogues.speaker: MAGWITCH
dialogues.text: This here ‘erbert - ?

dialogues.speaker: PIP
dialogues.text: At his parents. Away till tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: MAGWITCH
dialogues.text: Sit. Sit and give us half a minute. Nervously PIP sits opposite the stranger. He takes in the face of the man, wet and exhausted, watches as he reaches over and takes PIP’s hands, and kisses them with startlin humility. And PIP remembers. The Convict.

dialogues.speaker: PIP
dialogues.text: Good God -

dialogues.speaker: MAGWITCH
dialogues.text: You acted noble, my boy. Noble, Pip, and I have never forgot it.

dialogues.speaker: PIP
dialogues.text: If you're grateful for me for what I did as a boy, if you’ve come to thank me, it’s not necessary. But you must understand...

dialogues.speaker: MAGWITCH
dialogues.text: What must I understand?

dialogues.speaker: PIP
dialogues.text: That I cannot renew our acquaintance. My life has changed since then. I’m glad that you’re well and that you’ve repented. But really, you must go. Please, go, now. MAGWITCH takes this in.  GREAT EXPECTATIONS (PAGES 10/12) 74.

dialogues.speaker: MAGWITCH
dialogues.text: How about a drink first?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MAGWITCH pours rum into glasses.

dialogues.speaker: PIP
dialogues.text: How have you been living?

dialogues.speaker: MAGWITCH
dialogues.text: A sheep farmer, stock breeder, in the New World, many a thousand mile off.

dialogues.speaker: PIP
dialogues.text: You’ve done well?

dialogues.speaker: MAGWITCH
dialogues.text: I’ve done wonderful well. Seems you’ve done well too. MAGWITCH takes in the apartment.

dialogues.speaker: PIP
dialogues.text: I have, thank you, and I'd like, if I may, to give you this gift - (His pocket book-) A token. For old times. Before you go. Here — And he holds out a one pound note to the convict. MAGWITCH regards the money for a second; not insulted, just a little amused. He folds the money lengthwise, gives it a twist, holds it to the candle. As he watches it burn -

dialogues.speaker: MAGWITCH
dialogues.text: Might a varmint make so bold as to ask you how you have done well, since we were on those marshes?

dialogues.speaker: PIP
dialogues.text: I have come into some property.

dialogues.speaker: MAGWITCH
dialogues.text: And might a varmint ask whose property?

dialogues.speaker: PIP
dialogues.text: I cannot say her name. There are conditions.

dialogues.speaker: MAGWITCH
dialogues.text: Conditions. Hm. Could I make a guess as to your income? Might the first figure be...5?  GREAT EXPECTATIONS (PAGES 10/12) 75. And a terrible truth starts to dawn for PIP. In a great rush -

dialogues.speaker: MAGWITCH
dialogues.text: And a guardian, you will have had a guardian, a lawyer maybe, with a name beginning with a...J? (PIP stumbles to the door) A ‘J’ perhaps who might have sent me your address when I landed in Portsmouth? A Mr Jaggers p'raps? (and MAGWITCH is upon him, embracing him) Yes dear boy, I’ve made a gentleman of you! I swore that time as sure as I ever earned a guinea, that guinea should go to you. I lived rough so that you should live smooth, I worked hard that you should be above work. And when the blood horses of them colonists kicked up dirt in my face, and they called me a convict, a common fellow, I said to myself ‘I’m making a better gentleman than you will ever be’ (tears in his eyes now-) And Pip - you’re him! I made you! I’m your father, Pip.

dialogues.speaker: PIP
dialogues.text: You are not my father!

dialogues.speaker: MAGWITCH
dialogues.text: Your second father then, and you’re my son, no, more to me than any son! (His hands are on PIP’s face now, drinking in the sight of him) Look at you, dear boy! Look at these lodgings, fit for a lord, and this watch and this ring and your linen and your clothes. And your books too, hundreds of them! Read ‘em all, have you? You shall read’em to me, dear boy, and I shall be so proud to think that I’m the maker of such a man! And MAGWITCH’s arms are once again around his ‘son’, a so who feels nothing but fear and repulsion for this man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dawn is breaking as MAGWITCH lies in clean white linen, taking in his boy.  132 GREAT EXPECTATIONS (PAGES 10/12) 76.

dialogues.speaker: MAGWITCH
dialogues.text: How good-looking you've growed. Isn’t there bright eyes somewhere wot you love to think on? (PIP nods. MAGWITCH whispers) Then her eyes shall be yours too, dear boy, if money can buy ‘em. (PIP tries a smile) Now I must sleep, long and sound. A long time since I slept. You'll keep a watch, my boy?

dialogues.speaker: PIP
dialogues.text: I will.

dialogues.speaker: MAGWITCH
dialogues.text: Because, look here, caution is necessary. I was sent for life. It’s death to come back. I should be hanged if took.

dialogues.speaker: PIP
dialogues.text: You risked your life to come to me?

dialogues.speaker: MAGWITCH
dialogues.text: That’s right, dear boy.

dialogues.speaker: PIP
dialogues.text: But I don’t even know your name.

dialogues.speaker: MAGWITCH
dialogues.text: Magwitch. Abel Magwitch. And now, I think that I will sleep. And he closes his eyes, and is almost instantly asleep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Morning comes. PIP sits in the same spot, watching over the sleeping convict, taking in his coarse features, the creased, scarred face, the powerful, tattooed hands - his ‘father’. On the bedside table a jack-knife lies, huge and sinister its blade exposed, ready for use. On the mantelpiece, tightly-bound rolls of cash, high denomination notes, mor money than PIP has ever imagined. PIP holds one in his hand. Sunlight is on the pillow; MAGWITCH stirs. PIP returns th money to the pile, crosses to the curtain, and is about t pull it shut - Outside, in the park, a silhouetted figure in the dawn light. Tall, thin, sinister, he stares implacably at the window.  GREAT EXPECTATIONS (PAGES 10/12) 77. PIP pulls the curtain closed. 133 INT. JAGGER’S OFFICE, SMITHFIELD - DAY 133 PIP storms past WEMMICK into JAGGERS’ office, to find his guardian on his feet, uncharacteristically defensive.

dialogues.speaker: JAGGERS
dialogues.text: Now, Pip, be careful, be very careful...

dialogues.speaker: PIP
dialogues.text: Is it true?

dialogues.speaker: JAGGERS
dialogues.text: And don’t commit yourself, don’t tell me anything I don’t want to know...

dialogues.speaker: PIP
dialogues.text: Is what I have been told true?

dialogues.speaker: JAGGERS
dialogues.text: ‘Told’ implies verbal communication, you can’t have verbal communication with a man in New South Wales. (WEMMICK loiters) Wemmick, the door. WEMMICK pulls the door closed, and takes a seat.

dialogues.speaker: PIP
dialogues.text: I was led to believe -

dialogues.speaker: JAGGERS
dialogues.text: - nothing, Pip. You believed what you chose to believe. I am not responsible for that. Now, have an uncle staying with you at present, is that right? (PIP nods) Perhaps you might buy him some new clothes and advise him to reside in your rooms as much as possible. Perhaps your uncle might cut his hair. In the meantime- ( - a piece of paper -) - in writing to the gentleman in New South Wales, you might give him this. The balance of our accounts. My services are at an end. Good day, Mr Pip. But PIP doesn’t move. With measured fury -

dialogues.speaker: PIP
dialogues.text: All that time, in Satis House I was just a mechanical heart to practice on. Estella was never meant for me at all. And you, my ‘guardian’, have known this all along.  134 135 GREAT EXPECTATIONS (PAGES 10/12) 78. WEMMICK clears his throat - a look to JAGGERS.

dialogues.speaker: JAGGERS
dialogues.text: Well, I suppose you might as well hear it from me as anyone. The Spider has played his hand, Pip.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PIP, on horseback this time, arrives breathless and agitated at Satis House. He rides up to the front gate, dismounts, pulls urgently at the bell. A figure saunters towards the gate with an arrogant swagger. BENTLEY DRUMMLE, a supercilious grin plastered all over his face.

dialogues.speaker: DRUMMLE
dialogues.text: Can I help you?

dialogues.speaker: PIP
dialogues.text: Open this gate, Drummle, or I swear...

dialogues.speaker: DRUMMLE
dialogues.text: Why, it’s the ‘smithie’s boy! Don’t lose your temper, ‘smithie’s boy. Seems to me you’ve lost quite enough already... And he opens the gate. PIP barges past him, DRUMMLE’s mocking laughter ringing out behind him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MISS HAVISHAM and ESTELLA are in their usual place, the old lady petting the beautiful girl who, nevertheless, seems to carry an extra weight of sadness with her today.

dialogues.speaker: MISS HAVISHAM
dialogues.text: Pip! What wind has blown you -

dialogues.speaker: ENOUGH
dialogues.text: ESTELLA looks up, startled at PIP’s defiance. Yes, there is something of the knight-of-old about PIP this time.

dialogues.speaker: PIP
dialogues.text: What I have to say to Estella I will say before you. But Miss Havisham; when you first took me from my home, I came as a kind of servant, to gratify a whim and be paid for it.  GREAT EXPECTATIONS (PAGES 10/12) 79.

dialogues.speaker: MISS HAVISHAM
dialogues.text: Ay, Pip -

dialogues.speaker: PIP
dialogues.text: And when I fell into my mistake, of imagining that you were my benefactor -

dialogues.speaker: MISS HAVISHAM
dialogues.text: - I let you go on.

dialogues.speaker: PIP
dialogues.text: Was that...kind?

dialogues.speaker: KIND
dialogues.text: (with real rage) Who am I, for God’s sake, to be kind? It amused me, do you hear? To punish my relations. You were adequately paid I believe. What else do you want, Pip? And now PIP gathers himself, and turns to ESTELLA.

dialogues.speaker: PIP
dialogues.text: Estella, you know I love you, have loved you ever since I first saw you in this house. Foolishly I’d hoped that Miss Havisham had meant us for each other. Clearly the idea was absurd, and I hope Miss Havisham will take what pleasure she can from knowing that I am as unhappy as she ever meant me to be. MISS HAVISHAM flinches, puts her hand to her chest. ESTELLA stands, speaking in that steady voice of hers. A beat.

dialogues.speaker: ESTELLA
dialogues.text: It seems these are sentiments, emotions, that I am not able to comprehend. When you say you ‘love me’, I understand it as a form of words - (her heart -) - but it touches nothing here.

dialogues.speaker: PIP
dialogues.text: I don’t believe you.

dialogues.speaker: ESTELLA
dialogues.text: Did I not warn you?

dialogues.speaker: PIP
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: ESTELLA
dialogues.text: Did you think I did not mean it?  GREAT EXPECTATIONS (PAGES 10/12) 80.

dialogues.speaker: PIP
dialogues.text: No. It is not natural -

dialogues.speaker: ESTELLA
dialogues.text: (a flash of anger) It is natural in me!

dialogues.speaker: PIP
dialogues.text: And yet still I love you. I know that I‘1l never call you mine, Estella, but still I love you and beg you - Do not Marry Bentley Drummle. Someone else, anyone, but not that brute...

dialogues.speaker: ESTELLA
dialogues.text: Too late. A beat. ESTELLA looks to MISS HAVISHAM, then back to PIP.

dialogues.speaker: ESTELLA
dialogues.text: It's too late. I am going to marry him. The preparations are already under way.

dialogues.speaker: PIP
dialogues.text: You can’t let Miss Havisham...

dialogues.speaker: ESTELLA
dialogues.text: It is my own act. Miss Havisham has urged me to wait, to reconsider - She looks to MISS HAVISHAM, who looks away with what migh well be shame. With a defeated shrug -

dialogues.speaker: ESTELLA
dialogues.text: - but I am tired of my life. We will do well enough! (She holds out her hand) Give me your hand. (He does so. There are tears in both their eyes. A whisper) Be happy, Pip. This will pass in time. I‘1l be out of your thoughts in a week.

dialogues.speaker: PIP
dialogues.text: Out of my thoughts? You are part of my existence, part of me. You’re in every thought, in every line I have ever read since I first came here. You’re in the river, the sails of ships, the marshes, the clouds, the sea, the stones of London. Until the last hour of my life you will remain in me, part of the little good, part of the evil. (his face next to hers) And I will always think of the good. (a kiss) Goodbye. God bless you.  136 137 GREAT EXPECTATIONS (PAGES 10/12) 81. PIP is about to walk from the room, when -

dialogues.speaker: MISS HAVISHAM
dialogues.text: So proud, so hard. And, with startling ferocity, ESTELLA turns on her.

dialogues.speaker: ESTELLA
dialogues.text: I am what you made me! (eyes blazing) You are my mother, and yet I’ve never seen your face by daylight. Since I was a baby you taught me that was no such thing as daylight, that it had blighted you and would blight me too, if I let it. Well, I am what you made me. This is what you have made me! MISS HAVISHAM sits rigid, terrified beneath ESTELLA’s gaze. PIP speaks, breaking the spell.

dialogues.speaker: PIP
dialogues.text: Estella - come with me now. A moment, and ESTELLA turns and walks towards him. But her step slows and stops. MISS HAVISHAM is weeping, whimpering in her chair, pathetic, never more alone. PIP holds out his hand to ESTELLA. Her choice - But it’s no good. It’s too late. She looks back - And she returns to MISS HAVISHAM, placing her head in her lap once more, in that same mechanical movement. PIP watches the strange scene for a moment, then closes the door. EXT. WEMMICK’S HOUSE - DAY 136 The castle drawbridge descends, and WEMMICK stands in his nightshirt, taking in the dishevelled, confused PIP.

dialogues.speaker: WEMMICK
dialogues.text: Mr Pip, step inside sir, please - INT. WEMMICK’S PARLOUR, WALWORTH - DAY 137 As the AGED P nods away -  138 139 GREAT EXPECTATIONS (PAGES 10/12) 82.

dialogues.speaker: PIP
dialogues.text: I'd like to help Mr Pocket. He has been a loyal and decent friend and I’d like to use the money that remains to do one good thing. I’d like to purchase a position for him. Without his knowledge.

dialogues.speaker: WEMMICK
dialogues.text: Allowing for debts, which are considerable I might add, that’s five hundred pounds, sir. All invested in a friend?

dialogues.speaker: PIP
dialogues.text: Every last penny. What is your advice?

dialogues.speaker: WEMMICK
dialogues.text: Well, if I was in the Office, sir, I would suggest that you should take the five hundred pounds, choose your bridge - there are six to choose from up as high as Chelsea Reach - and throw the money off it. You’1ll lose it just the same, but it'll be quicker. Those are my sentiments, in the office.

dialogues.speaker: PIP
dialogues.text: But your home sentiments, your Walworth sentiments?

dialogues.speaker: WEMMICK
dialogues.text: My Walworth sentiments would be - I'11 see what I can do. Ain’t that right, Aged

dialogues.speaker: AGED P
dialogues.text: Yes, John, my boy. And PIP watches as the father and son nod and wink, nod and wink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's very late now as PIP returns. He looks anxiously up at the window of his apartment. He has been away too long he must hurry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He rushes into the rooms, and hears a faint knocking, a muffled moan, a whisper. Tentatively, he walks down the hall and discovers - HERBERT, held high against the wall, his heels kicking th floor, MAGWITCH’s big hand covering his mouth, the jack- knife in the other. Terror in HERBERT’s eyes -  GREAT EXPECTATIONS (PAGES 10/12) 83.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PIP and HERBERT sit in their usual spot, HERBERT drinking a medicinal brandy with a tremulous hand.

dialogues.speaker: PIP
dialogues.text: He wishes to buy us a house! In Hyde Park! A coach, horses...

dialogues.speaker: HERBERT
dialogues.text: Can’t you...accept?

dialogues.speaker: PIP
dialogues.text: How can I?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MAGWITCH is listening in; thoughtful, sad.

dialogues.speaker: PIP, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: I’ve seen him try to murder a man. He might have murdered you -

dialogues.speaker: HERBERT, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: And yet he risked his life to find you.

dialogues.speaker: PIP, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: He says...he says I am the son he never had. MAGWITCH frowns. The contempt in PIP’s voice is plain to hear.

dialogues.speaker: PIP
dialogues.text: ...The idea appals me, Herbert, but even so, he must not be captured, not on my behalf. He stops speaking. MAGWITCH is there.

dialogues.speaker: MAGWITCH
dialogues.text: Gentlemen -

dialogues.speaker: MAGWITCH
dialogues.text: Now, dear boy, and Pip’s comrade, I’m not going to tell you my life like a song or story-book, but to give it to you short and handy. In jail and out of jail, in jail, out of jail. That’s my life - until I met my boy here. (a proud look) (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 144 145 GREAT EXPECTATIONS (PAGES 10/12) 84.

dialogues.speaker: MAGWITCH, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: I’ve been done everything to except hanged. I’ve tramped and begged and thieved and poached, anything that doesn’t pay and leads to trouble. And then a matter over twenty years ago, when I was out of money and out of luck - not that I’d been in it much - I met a man. At Epsom races. His name was Compeyson and if I had him here I’d crack his skull like the claw of a lobster. HERBERT starts. MAGWITCH looks to him.

dialogues.speaker: HERBERT
dialogues.text: Compeyson?

dialogues.speaker: MAGWITCH
dialogues.text: Compeyson.

dialogues.speaker: HERBERT
dialogues.text: I’m sorry. Go on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the corner sits COMPEYSON, good-looking, saturnine.

dialogues.speaker: MAGWITCH
dialogues.text: A gentleman was Compeyson, a smooth one, and good-looking too, went to boarding school. He and his missus had a plan... Clinging to his arm is his wife, MRS COMPEYSON, beautiful elegant, dark. MAGWITCH and another UNSEEN MAN listen in.

dialogues.speaker: MAGWITCH, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: ...involving the defrauding of a certain lady by her half-brother... REVEAL the other man is ARTHUR HAVISHAM.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A wedding cake. Extravagant, ornate, it stands as the centre-piece of a long banquet table in an elegant, light filled room.

dialogues.speaker: MAGWITCH, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Weren’t much of a plan to my mind, but I played my part in a small way... SERVANTS buzz around the table in preparation for the wedding feast. Life, activity everywhere. The MESSENGER walks past all this, as before -  146 147 148 149 GREAT EXPECTATIONS (PAGES 10/12) 85.

dialogues.speaker: MAGWITCH, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I played my part, though I can’t say I’m proud of it... - only now REVEAL the carrier of the letter to be MAGWITCH.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Watching from a carriage at the end of the drive, COMPEYSON and MRS COMPEYSON. MAGWITCH joins them.

dialogues.speaker: COMPEYSON
dialogues.text: Well done, Abel. From Satis House, a terrible scream. MAGWITCH, uncomfortable, ashamed.

dialogues.speaker: MAGWITCH, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Oh, for a while, there was money. A whole lot of money, and we betted and gamed and drank our way through it...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A squalid rented room. ARTHUR lies shivering on the filth mattress.

dialogues.speaker: MAGWITCH, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: +..’til one of our number went to the bad, turned to drink, opium, lost his mind... C.U. on ARTHUR HAVISHAM as he takes a deep breath, closes his eyes, mumbles something -

dialogues.speaker: ARTHUR HAVISHAM
dialogues.text: Forgive me. - and drops out of sight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On MAGWITCH, a haunted look in his eye as he recalls.

dialogues.speaker: MAGWITCH
dialogues.text: Bad conscience, I s’pose.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ARTHUR HAVISHAM hangs dead from a home-made noose.  150 151 152 GREAT EXPECTATIONS (PAGES 10/12) 86.

dialogues.speaker: MAGWITCH, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: ‘Course conscience wasn’t summat that'd trouble Compeyson. Cold as death he was. REVEAL COMPEYSON, MRS COMPEYSON and MAGWITCH regarding th dangling corpse.

dialogues.speaker: COMPEYSON
dialogues.text: Cut him down, Abel. INT. SITTING ROOM, MAYFAIR APARTMENTS —- NIGHT 150

dialogues.speaker: MAGWITCH
dialogues.text: That was a dark time, the time wi’ Compeyson. Always in debt to him, always under his thumb, always working, always a- getting into danger, for years and years, until I was his black slave. He was younger than me, but he’d got craft and he'd got learning. I had a missis at that time -

dialogues.speaker: PIP
dialogues.text: You were married?

dialogues.speaker: MAGWITCH
dialogues.text: (He hesitates) No matter. The short of it is. We got committed for felony, putting forged notes into circulation. ‘Separate defences,’ Compeyson says, ‘no communication’.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the dock stands MAGWITCH, a forlorn sight.

dialogues.speaker: MAGWITCH, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I sold everything, all but the clothes on my back, so I could get Jaggers... As JAGGERS holds forth, MAGWITCH’s eyes drift up to the public gallery, where a BABY cries. MRS MAGWITCH greatly upset, presses her face to the weeping child. WE DO NOT SEE HER FACE YET.

dialogues.speaker: MAGWITCH, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: --.-for all the good it did me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: COMPEYSON in the dock; well-dressed, penitent, respectabl as his LAWYER holds forth.  153 154 GREAT EXPECTATIONS (PAGES 10/12) 87.

dialogues.speaker: MAGWITCH, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Says the counsellor for Compeyson, wasn’t he the younger and well brought-up and of a good school? Wasn’t he a gentleman? Jump cut; The JUDGE is speaking now.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE MAGWITCH, (V.0)
dialogues.text: Abel Magwitch, you have, And when the verdict came almost since your infancy, warn’t it Compeyson as was been an offender against recommended to mercy on our laws despite repeated account of good character imprisonments and and bad company and all the punishments. Given your damn’'d lies he gave up persistence and your malign against me and warn’t it me influence on your gentleman as got never a word but accomplice here, I have no guilty, guilty, guilty! choice but to find you guilty on all charges and to sentence you to fourteen years imprisonment... As the JUDGE pronounces the sentence MAGWITCH flies at COMPEYSON, who grins back, maddeningly, infuriatingly as MAGWITCH is dragged from the dock by the turnkeys. One last look to the gallery. MRS MAGWITCH, face obscured holds up the BABY. It's the last thing MAGWITCH sees before he’s dragged int blackness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A shaken MAGWITCH wipes his brow, and gathers himself.

dialogues.speaker: PIP
dialogues.text: For how long - ?

dialogues.speaker: MAGWITCH
dialogues.text: Fourteen years. He got seven. Then five years on, he turns up on my prison ship. I swore to the Lord I’d smash his face in, and I did -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A blow strikes convict COMPEYSON full in the face. The deck of the hulk acts as an exercise yard for the desolate PRISONERS, who stand now, shouting and jeering, as MAGWITCH assaults a terrified COMPEYSON. A lash of his chains slashes COMPEYSON’s cheek, and now the chain is round his neck. COMPEYSON is in his grasp -  GREAT EXPECTATIONS (PAGES 10/12) 87A. A GUARD draws a pistol, another a rifle. MAGWITCH and his hostage back away. MAGWITCH’s back is against the bulwark The GUARDS raise their guns... A moment. Then with a push of his powerful legs, MAGWITCH pitches backwards, dragging his hostage with him. They tumble towards the black Thames far below -  155 156 157

dialogues.speaker: DAY, (FLASHBACK)
dialogues.text: MAGWITCH peers through the gloom of Grapeshot breaks the surface as the glimpse of COMPEYSON, eyes bulging, darkness... 10/12) 88. 155 the dank water. GUARDS open fire. A sinking away into the INT. SITTING ROOM, MAYFAIR APARTMENTS —- NIGHT 156

dialogues.speaker: MAGWITCH
dialogues.text: Thinking, hoping, that he’d drowned I swam to the shore and was hiding among the graves there, envying those that were in ‘em - (he takes PIP’s hands) - when my boy here found me. My boy. PIP finally speaks.

dialogues.speaker: PIP
dialogues.text: Is he dead?

dialogues.speaker: MAGWITCH
dialogues.text: Who?

dialogues.speaker: PIP
dialogues.text: Compeyson.

dialogues.speaker: MAGWITCH
dialogues.text: He'll wish I am, if he’s alive. And he’1l wish he was, if I find him.

dialogues.speaker: PIP
dialogues.text: And the lady he defrauded. Her name was -

dialogues.speaker: MAGWITCH
dialogues.text: ‘Avisham. Miss ‘Avisham.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 157 The next morning. MAGWITCH sits in front of a mirror, a towel draped around his shoulders, as PIP cuts his long grey hair, still wary, but with a new sympathy.

dialogues.speaker: PIP
dialogues.text: I was thinking, perhaps, we might take a trip abroad. Until we can is safe here.

dialogues.speaker: MAGWITCH
dialogues.text: Together?

dialogues.speaker: PIP
dialogues.text: Of course. be sure that it  158 159 GREAT EXPECTATIONS (PAGES 10/12) 89. MAGWITCH reaches up and takes the hand that holds the scissors.

dialogues.speaker: MAGWITCH
dialogues.text: The idea don’t ‘appal’ you? And PIP realises that he must have been overheard.

dialogues.speaker: PIP
dialogues.text: Of course not. A beat, and the haircut continues.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A black-clad figure marches through the crowds. His colla is raised, though not so far as to disguise a livid red scar on his sallow cheeks. COMPEYSON. He’s in pursuit of PIP, pushing through the morning crowds, glancing behind him as he goes. Anxious, troubled, PIP arrives at JAGGER’s home. The door is opened by MOLLY. INT. DRESSING ROOM, JAGGERS’ OFFICE - DAY 159 JAGGERS stands at the basin, washing his hands with more than usual thoroughness.

dialogues.speaker: PIP
dialogues.text: I need you to tell me about Compeyson. Without turning round, JAGGERS is still, just for a minute, before regaining his composure. He dries his hands.

dialogues.speaker: JAGGERS
dialogues.text: Compeyson. Yes, I remember a Compeyson. Clever fellow. Dangerous.

dialogues.speaker: PIP
dialogues.text: And is he still alive?

dialogues.speaker: JAGGERS
dialogues.text: To my knowledge, yes he is. (He turns to PIP) I did the best that I could by your friend. The penalty for passing stolen notes is life. He was lucky to get fourteen years.

dialogues.speaker: PIP
dialogues.text: ‘Lucky’!  GREAT EXPECTATIONS (PAGES 10/12) 90.

dialogues.speaker: JAGGERS
dialogues.text: As to Compeyson, I'd strongly advise your Uncle to pack his bags. If he’s found, he’ll hang, and it’s safe to presume that Mr Compeyson does not wish him well... And JAGGERS freezes. Someone has entered the room. MOLLY stands shaking, a terrible mania in her wide eyes.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: He’s back. Abel’s come back. You told me he’d never come back.

dialogues.speaker: JAGGERS
dialogues.text: Calm now, Molly -

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: He mustn’t find out, ever. Poor, poor Abel. What did you make me do! It was wicked, wicked -

dialogues.speaker: JAGGERS
dialogues.text: Abel won’t find out, I’1l make sure of it. Didn't I swear to you he would never - She’s on JAGGERS now -

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: You swore that she’d be safe! You swore she'd have a brand new life and now he’s back and Compeyson too. That man will kill me if he finds me...

dialogues.speaker: JAGGERS
dialogues.text: Shhh, now, that’s enough. No-one will ever find you, or her. She’s safe, no-one can touch her now, you have my word.

dialogues.speaker: MOLLY
dialogues.text: Your word! Damn your soul, Jaggers, damn it to hell! And all of a sudden all the strength goes out of MOLLY, and she falls to the floor, weeping. PIP looks on at the strange sight, and a terrible truth dawns. JAGGERS looks to him, shaken. No choice now but to tell the story.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A private coach heads through the countryside at great speed.  161 162 163 164 GREAT EXPECTATIONS (PAGES 10/12) 91.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The darkened coach has something of the air of a confessional. C.U. of a visibly shaken JAGGERS.

dialogues.speaker: JAGGERS
dialogues.text: Magwitch and Molly had a child. A girl. A pretty thing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MAGWITCH is dragged down into jail, stealing one last glimpse of the BABY, being held aloft to him by the WEEPING WOMAN - MOLLY.

dialogues.speaker: JAGGERS, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: But Molly was a fierce one, wild and passionate like her husband, and not a girl to let injustice go unpunished. It’s the last time MAGWITCH will ever see his child.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A figure watches as MRS COMPEYSON sleeps comfortably in her bed. But something makes her stir. She opens her eyes and sees; MOLLY MAGWITCH. Before she can scream, MOLLY’s hands are around her neck. MRS COMPEYSON’s hands claw at MOLLY’s arms, the nails digging deep into her attacker’s wrists - the source of the scars. But her attacker is too strong. MRS COMPEYSON’s eyes bulg in her head, her tongue swells horribly in her mouth. MOLLY watches this, implacable, cold. And soon MRS COMPEYSON lies dead.

dialogues.speaker: JAGGERS
dialogues.text: A terrible crime, cold-blooded and ruthless. Assuming of course that Molly did it.

dialogues.speaker: PIP
dialogues.text: And did she?

dialogues.speaker: JAGGERS
dialogues.text: To be guilty and to be found guilty are not the same thing at all. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: JAGGERS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (A deep breath; almost a confession) Put the case that a woman, accused of murder, came to her legal adviser, and put the case that this same legal adviser held a trust to find a child for an eccentric rich lady to adopt and bring up. Put the case that he lived in an atmosphere of evil where children were generated in great numbers for certain destruction, habitually whipped, imprisoned, transported, neglected, abused in ways that you can hardly imagine. Put the case that there was one pretty little child out of the heap who could be saved. Put the case that the legal adviser said to the mother - 165 INT. JAGGERS’ OFFICE, SMITHFIELD - NIGHT (FLASHBACK) Late at night, JAGGERS interrogates the weeping MOLLY.

dialogues.speaker: JAGGERS
dialogues.text: Give the child into my hands, and I will do my best to get you off. If you are saved, your child is saved; if you are lost, your child is saved too. JAGGERS speaks in the moment now, whispering in her ear. And MOLLY makes her decision.

dialogues.speaker: PIP
dialogues.text: And the child was your fee? (JAGGERS says nothing) And what of Magwitch?

dialogues.speaker: JAGGERS
dialogues.text: The father was told...

dialogues.speaker: PIP
dialogues.text: Say his name!

dialogues.speaker: JAGGERS
dialogues.text: Magwitch was told that his child was dead. Consumption. (PIP regards JAGGERS with utter contempt) Put the case that the child was now safe. Wealthy. Soon to be married to one of the richest men in England.

dialogues.speaker: PIP
dialogues.text: And one of the vilest.  GREAT EXPECTATIONS (PAGES 10/12) 93.

dialogues.speaker: JAGGERS
dialogues.text: Estella is not the Spider’s reward. Estella is his punishment.

dialogues.speaker: PIP
dialogues.text: And you arranged it.

dialogues.speaker: JAGGERS
dialogues.text: As instructed by my client. Only as instructed. The coach comes to a halt.

dialogues.speaker: PIP
dialogues.text: And what did Miss Havisham want with the child?

dialogues.speaker: JAGGERS
dialogues.text: That - (opens the coach door) - you must ask her yourself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Satis House stands before PIP, gloomier than ever. PIP steps down from the coach and approaches the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The exact spot, sixteen years before. JAGGERS steps down from the coach and approaches. He carries a bundle in his arms. A three year-old child, beautiful - THE INFANT ESTELLA.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PIP climbs the gloomy staircase.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The INFANT ESTELLA steps climbs the gloomy staircase, her tiny hand in JAGGERS’ well-manicured fist.  172 173 174

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PIP stands at the door to MISS HAVISHAM’s room. He pushes at the door and -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MISS HAVISHAM, some sixteen years younger than in the PRESENT, is seated at her place at the bridal banquet. A fire throws strange shadows onto the wall. Alone in this blacked-out room, with the strange veiled figure all in white, the infant ESTELLA is terrified. She glances towards the banquet, already mouldering and corrupted after six years of decay. INFANT ESTELLA looks to JAGGERS for aid, but he is alread stepping backwards towards the door. He looks shaken. And now the woman in white is holding out her hand. A glimpse of her face beneath the veil.

dialogues.speaker: MISS HAVISHAM
dialogues.text: Come nearer. Don’t be frightened - (ESTELLA steps forward) Come nearer. Let me look at you - In voice-over, we hear...

dialogues.speaker: MISS HAVISHAM, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: I wanted a little girl, to rear and to love and save from my fate. One night he brought her here and I called her -

dialogues.speaker: MISS HAVISHAM
dialogues.text: Estella.

dialogues.speaker: MISS HAVISHAM, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Oh, Pip, she was so gentle, so beautiful. And the INFANT ESTELLA moves towards the outstretched hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Back in the PRESENT, MISS HAVISHAM leans forward, speakin in an urgent whisper. A fire throws strange shadows on th wall -

dialogues.speaker: MISS HAVISHAM
dialogues.text: Pip, my dear, believe this: when she first came to me I meant to save her from misery like my own -  175 176 177 GREAT EXPECTATIONS (PAGES 10/12) 95.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The INFANT ESTELLA reaches her tiny hand out to MISS HAVISHAM. Behind her veil, MISS HAVISHAM smiles.

dialogues.speaker: MISS HAVISHAM
dialogues.text: ...-but as she grew more beautiful, I gradually did worse, and with my praises and my jewels and my teachings, I stole her heart away and put ice in its place! (Pip has had enough. He walks away) Oh Pip, are you very unhappy? Do you hate me very much? I know that you must hate me, but if you can ever bear to forgive me, Pip... She follows him. But the long train of MISS HAVISHAM’s wedding dress is uncoiling behind her, knocking a table. A candle falls, igniting the desiccated material. It burns, the flames catching with startling speed, burning through the dress like a fuse. And now MISS HAVISHAM becomes aware of the flames behind her, writhing as they catch the dried silk and organza an lace, the flames burning around her as she screams and grabs the table-cloth. The rotting wedding-cake, the glas and crockery, the rats and beetles and spiders, fall to the floor. Helplessly, PIP swats at the flames, burning his hands, then grabs the curtains, tears them down, the dawn light pouring in, rats and spiders fleeing the light. He wraps the fabric round MISS HAVISHAM, holding her tight until the flames are extinguished. The wedding-cake lies shattered on the floor. And now JAGGERS bursts into the smoke-filled room. Ashes float in the air like confetti, and PIP sits and cradles MISS HAVISHAM as she lies, frozen in shock, her breath coming in short bursts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PIP sits in MISS HAVISHAM’s old chair as JAGGERS carefull bandages his burnt hands. In a low voice, all swagger gone;

dialogues.speaker: JAGGERS
dialogues.text: I do not deny that there have been..too many secrets. But who does the truth serve? (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 178 179 180 GREAT EXPECTATIONS (PAGES 10/12) 96.

dialogues.speaker: JAGGERS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: If she were to discover that her father is a convict, her mother a murderess? Would she thank you, do you think?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MISS HAVISHAM lies in her room. A surreal sight, she has been wrapped entirely in cotton wool and bandage, a strange mummy-like creature, only her face exposed. Her thin lips mutter the same words over and over again. PIP approaches to hear better. Her incantation;

dialogues.speaker: MISS HAVISHAM
dialogues.text: .-.-forgive me forgive me forgive me forgive me forgive me... PIP bends and gently kisses her hairline. Still the incantation doesn’t stop. PIP walks away, never to return.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: His burnt hands bandaged, pale and deprived of sleep, PIP heads back to his Mayfair apartments. He is walking acros the courtyard when a voice calls out to him; The PORTER.

dialogues.speaker: PORTER
dialogues.text: Sir! A note for you. Most important the gentleman said. PIP takes the note. It reads; DON’T GO HOME. W. PIP glances towards the apartment. Sure enough, TWO FIGURES stand menacingly by the door. They meet his gaze. Plain-clothes policemen? Criminals? PIP doesn’t wait to find out. Stepping backwards, he turns and runs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thick fog. PIP walks behind a shifty-looking WEMMICK.

dialogues.speaker: WEMMICK
dialogues.text: Did you destroy my note?

dialogues.speaker: PIP
dialogues.text: I did.

dialogues.speaker: WEMMICK
dialogues.text: Best not to leave any evidence. They’re on to him, Mr Pip. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: WEMMICK, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: The reward on his head is substantial. Every copper and cut-throat in London is on the hunt for your Antipodean Uncle. It was all your Mr Herbert and I could do to get him out in time -

dialogues.speaker: WEMMICK
dialogues.text: There’s a steamer leaving for Antwerp tomorrow at midnight. I suggest you and your Uncle find a way onto it- (in a low, discreet voice) Portable property, Mr Pip. Try and lay hold of the portable property. And with a shiver, PIP takes in WEMMICK’s hand; the dead mens’ rings on his fingers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PIP enters the strange, tumble-down building and is immediately embraced by HERBERT. CLARA’s there too.

dialogues.speaker: HERBERT
dialogues.text: All is well, Handel, he’ll be quite safe here, though he is keen to see you. Goodness me, what has happened to your hands?

dialogues.speaker: PIP
dialogues.text: Where is he? The father of the woman he loves stands. On seeing PIP, MAGWITCH’s face lights up. A look of immense, paternal pride.

dialogues.speaker: PIP
dialogues.text: The steamer departs at midnight, we'll intercept it shortly after. The further from the city we can get, the safer it will be. Not long now.

dialogues.speaker: MAGWITCH
dialogues.text: Thank ‘ee, my dear boy. CLARA is saying goodbye to HERBERT.

dialogues.speaker: PIP
dialogues.text: Clara, I'll return your fiancé safely, I swear — But CLARA turns and walks briskly away -  GREAT EXPECTATIONS (PAGES 10/12) 97A.

dialogues.speaker: HERBERT
dialogues.text: Apologies, Handel. The fact is - well, she thinks you’re rather a malign influence on me.

dialogues.speaker: PIP
dialogues.text: And she’s right. Herbert, are you sure you want to...

dialogues.speaker: HERBERT
dialogues.text: Handel, I don’t think I’ve ever been more excited in my life!

dialogues.speaker: OMITTED 183
dialogues.text: 184 185 186 GREAT EXPECTATIONS (PAGES 10/12) 98.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Afternoon now. The fog has lifted. PIP, HERBERT and MAGWITCH walk down the muddy shore towards a rowing boat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As MAGWITCH sits in the prow, PIP and HERBERT row with al their might. The city is behind them now, the river opening out into an estuary and marshland. Pulling hard at the oars, PIP glances down at his burnt hands. The blisters have burst, and blood is seeping through the bandages. He holds on to the oars, and rows on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The journey continues, past Gravesend now, the spring day fresh but bright. PIP glances to his side; The prison hulks are there, menacing and dark. PIP glance to MAGWITCH, who also watches the hulks. A look to PIP, a acknowledgement between them. HERBERT glances over his shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: HERBERT
dialogues.text: We seem to have lost them - (PIP’s look - who?) I thought I saw another boat. (PIP looks round anxiously) Gone now. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: HERBERT, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: (HERBERT sees the blood on PIP’s hands) Let’s rest by the bank. They row towards the reed-beds.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The boat nestles in a quiet bay, their hiding place until the steamer arrives. While HERBERT keeps watch, PIP reads to MAGWITCH, who sit smoking in the spring sun, silent and introspective.

dialogues.speaker: PIP
dialogues.text: You seem despondent, Abel.

dialogues.speaker: MAGWITCH
dialogues.text: Not a bit of it. To sit here and have my smoke alonger my dear boy... (He breaks off.) I had a little child once. I didn’t tell you afore. Pretty little thing, a girl. Died while I was in prison. ‘Appens often enough, but I tell you dear boy, there weren’t a day as I was rotting on that hulk when I didn’t think on her face, and what a dear pretty thing she were. And when I saw you on those marshes, well, you brought her to my mind, and p’rhaps that’s why I took to you so strong. You two'd been about the same age. Now I knows I’m no father to you, my dear boy. You had a father and lost him, and an old varmint like me ain’t about to replace him. But I hope as I’ve been a friend to you this little time we've had.

dialogues.speaker: PIP
dialogues.text: You speak as if we were parting. In an hour we'll be safe again.

dialogues.speaker: MAGWITCH
dialogues.text: Well perhaps we will and perhaps we won't. He places his hand over the side of the boat, and lets hi fingertips run through the water.

dialogues.speaker: MAGWITCH
dialogues.text: We can no more see to the bottom of the next few hours than we can see to the bottom of this river, no more hold their tide than I can hold this. And it’s run through my fingers... (holds up his hand) -.-and gone. You see?  188 GREAT EXPECTATIONS (PAGES 10/12) 100. They say no more. A moment passes.

dialogues.speaker: HERBERT
dialogues.text: Listen! Can you hear?...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HERBERT and PIP pull as hard as they can to the centre of the river. Sure enough, the steamer is approaching, paddles churning the water, the means of their escape. But before it, a dreadful sight. The Thames River Police, twelve strong uniformed men, giving their boat a formidable pace. PIP shoots a look to MAGWITCH, who seems resigned. Nevertheless, PIP and HERBERT continue to row into the path of the steamer - - which now sounds its horn in warning. The Police Boat is making fast progress too. An officer stands at the helm;

dialogues.speaker: RIVER POLICE
dialogues.text: You have a returned convict there! His name is Abel Magwitch. I apprehend the man, and call upon him to surrender! Against all hope, PIP and HERBERT continue to row. PIP glances back at the advancing boat, and the steamer behin it, its horn sounding once more. In the Police Boat, a black-clad figure cowers. COMPEYSON the dark, scarred face clearly visible. MAGWITCH sees him too. PIP sees a momentary glimpse of th jack-knife, clenched in MAGWITCH’s hand, the brutality of old returning to his face. And now the police boat is beside them, POLICEMEN clingin on to the side in preparation for the arrest. But too late. With a terrible cry, MAGWITCH hurls himself onto a terrified COMPEYSON, knocking him backwards into the water - Horns blare - And now the steamboat is suddenly upon them, great paddle chewing through PIP’s boat like matchwood. PIP and HERBER hurl themselves into the water, turning just in time to see a furious thrashing, a glimpse of a screaming face, a MAGWITCH and COMPEYSON are dragged beneath the steamer’s churning paddles.  189 190 191 GREAT EXPECTATIONS (PAGES 10/12) 101. Strong arms haul PIP into the police galley. He tries to break free, to throw himself after MAGWITCH, but the POLICEMEN hold him tight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The steamer has sailed on. The water is calmer now, and covered with debris. As PIP scans the surface, hope fading, he reaches for some of the debris; Paper. Money. Five, ten pound notes, hundreds of pounds- worth, sodden and useless.

dialogues.speaker: POLICEMAN
dialogues.text: Over there! And a black shape bobs on the surface; MAGWITCH. He is hauled into the boat. Blood seeps from a gash in hi head, and his breathing is painful and laboured. PIP places his arms round the man’s shoulders, as his eyes flicker open. An impassioned whisper -

dialogues.speaker: PIP
dialogues.text: I will not leave you, do you hear me? Whatever happens from now on, I'll be by your side. And MAGWITCH grasps PIP’s hand and holds it tight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the sun sets, the galley heads back towards the city. His breath coming in gasps, MAGWITCH lies in PIP’s arms. INT. PRISON —- DAY 191 MAGWITCH lies in his cell, his chest and head bandaged, a JAGGERS confers with him. PIP, bruised and pale, watches.

dialogues.speaker: JAGGERS
dialogues.text: All’s gone. All’s lost. You’ve let the whole thing slip through your fingers...

dialogues.speaker: PIP
dialogues.text: Will he be tried?

dialogues.speaker: JAGGERS
dialogues.text: Yes, he'll be tried and found guilty too, and hanged. The best that we can hope for is that he dies before it comes to that. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 192 193 194 GREAT EXPECTATIONS (PAGES 10/12) 102.

dialogues.speaker: JAGGERS, (CONT'D)
dialogues.text: The money, the land is all forfeit to the crown. You have nothing, Pip. Not a penny.

dialogues.speaker: PIP
dialogues.text: Can we keep that from him? (A look from JAGGERS) I'd like him to think that I’ma gentleman still.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Another day. PIP sits in MAGWITCH’s cell, reading Shakespeare. MAGWITCH lies quietly, his breath coming in gasps.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PIP pushes MAGWITCH in his wheelchair along a corridor. He’s in his respectable best, but nothing can disguise th deterioration in his condition.

dialogues.speaker: MAGWITCH
dialogues.text: Best a gentleman should not be knowed to belong to me now. Sit where I can see you and I don’t ask no more.

dialogues.speaker: PIP
dialogues.text: Nonsense. I'll be right by your side. MAGWITCH smiles, and we REVEAL -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: - the dock of the courtroom, where MAGWITCH joins thirty or so other PRISONERS, men and women, all awaiting sentence. A spring rain falls on the great high windows of the cour room. As the judge takes his place, PIP takes his seat just to the side of the dock.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE
dialogues.text: I must, amongst you, single out a miserable man who, after many years of living a peaceable and honest life in exile decided, in a fatal moment, to return to the country where he was expressly proscribed. Whatever the motive for his return, there can be only one punishment, a punishment which he shall share with all of you here before me today...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The JUDGE solemnly reaches for the square of black silk which he places on his head. We see the faces of the guilty; some defiant, some sobbin and weeping, some covering their faces, some staring morosely as the JUDGE delivers the communal sentence.

dialogues.speaker: JUDGE
dialogues.text: By the power vested in me by this court, I sentence you all to death by hanging...  GREAT EXPECTATIONS (PAGES 10/12) 103. Gasps, sobs, screams, sighs from the thirty-two convicted men and women. But with immense dignity MAGWITCH keeps his eyes fixed forward, his great hand clasped in PIP’s.

dialogues.speaker: HERBERT
dialogues.text: Dear Handel, I am very much afraid that I must leave you when you most need me.

dialogues.speaker: PIP
dialogues.text: Herbert?

dialogues.speaker: HERBERT
dialogues.text: The fact is it seems that I have... expectations.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HERBERT is about to board his coach.

dialogues.speaker: HERBERT
dialogues.text: It’s a small firm, run by a Mr Clarriker, of Liverpool, and I’m to be given a partnership! Completely out of the blue! Clara is most excited. We can marry now, at last.

dialogues.speaker: PIP
dialogues.text: I’m delighted for you, Herbert. It’s wonderful news.

dialogues.speaker: HERBERT
dialogues.text: And what of you, Pip? Do you have any plans? Because in this branch of ours I am going to need a... (here goes -) One, two, three —

dialogues.speaker: PIP
dialogues.text: A clerk?

dialogues.speaker: HERBERT
dialogues.text: Say that you will think upon it, in a few months, when...this is over.

dialogues.speaker: PIP
dialogues.text: I will.

dialogues.speaker: HERBERT
dialogues.text: (they embrace) We did have some adventures, didn’t we?  GREAT EXPECTATIONS (PAGES 10/12) 103A.

dialogues.speaker: PIP
dialogues.text: We did. We did.  195 196 GREAT EXPECTATIONS (PAGES 10/12) 104.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Another visit. MAGWITCH is lying on his bed, eyes fixed o the ceiling, breath coming in gasps. PIP looks to the WARDER, who shakes his head - ‘Not long now.’ PIP crouche close.

dialogues.speaker: PIP
dialogues.text: Are you in much pain today?

dialogues.speaker: MAGWITCH
dialogues.text: I don’t complain, dear boy.

dialogues.speaker: PIP
dialogues.text: You never do. (PIP is crying now.) If you had stayed away -

dialogues.speaker: MAGWITCH
dialogues.text: And not seen this face, dear boy?

dialogues.speaker: PIP
dialogues.text: I wish...I had been more deserving of your love.

dialogues.speaker: MAGWITCH
dialogues.text: Hush. A gentleman. My very own. His breath is very laboured now. PIP leans in -

dialogues.speaker: PIP
dialogues.text: Magwitch, I must tell you. You had a child once, whom you loved and lost - MAGWITCH turns his eyes to PIP.

dialogues.speaker: PIP
dialogues.text: She lived. She lived, and found powerful friends. She is living now. She is a lady and very beautiful. And I love her. MAGWITCH’s eyes are wet now. A profound joy. With one last effort, he lifts PIP’s hand to his lips and kisses it. MAGWITCH closes his eyes...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A wordless scene. A bright spring Sunday morning twenty years before. MAGWITCH and MOLLY lie in tangled sheets, MOLLY’s sleepin head upon her husband’s shoulder.  197 198 199 GREAT EXPECTATIONS (PAGES 10/12) 105.
