In MAGWITCH’s arms is the baby ESTELLA, laughing, gurgling, her small hands reaching for her father’s face. MAGWITCH presses his face against his beautiful baby daughter, taking in the smell of her. He smiles, and laughs and laughs...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MAGWITCH lies dead. PIP sits in silence, holding his hand unwilling now to let go. FADE TO BLACK.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PIP, in the throes of fever, opens his eyes with some effort. TWO BURLY MEN stand over him: Debt Collectors.

dialogues.speaker: PIP
dialogues.text: I don’t know you.

dialogues.speaker: BAILIFF ONE
dialogues.text: Concerns a debt, sir, of-

dialogues.speaker: BAILIFF TWO
dialogues.text: One hundred and twenty-five pounds, fifteen and six. Bleary-eyed, PIP looks around. The place has been strippe of all furniture, all paintings, even the curtains. PEPPER, the vengeful MAN-SERVANT is nonchalantly filling his pockets with silver cutlery. Merry whistling accompanies the burglary.

dialogues.speaker: PIP
dialogues.text: I don’t have it.

dialogues.speaker: BAILIFF ONE
dialogues.text: No, we thought not, sir -

dialogues.speaker: BAILIFF TWO
dialogues.text: - so we’ve come to arrest you.

dialogues.speaker: BAILIFF ONE
dialogues.text: If you'd like to come with us, sir.

dialogues.speaker: PIP
dialogues.text: Yes. Yes, of course -  GREAT EXPECTATIONS (PAGES 10/12) 106. And PIP pulls back the sheet, and tries to stand, and promptly faints away.

dialogues.speaker: VOICE
dialogues.text: Pip? Oh, Pi-ip...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PIP opens his eyes, and stares at the ceiling a moment. H turns his head on the pillow and sees - JOE GARGERY, his large head on the pillow next to him.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Hullo there.

dialogues.speaker: PIP
dialogues.text: Is it...Joe?

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Which it is, old chap. And he smiles his old smile.

dialogues.speaker: PIP
dialogues.text: Oh, Joe, you break my heart. Forgive me, will you Joe? For my ingratitude...

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Dear old Pip, old chap, you and me was ever friends. Now you sleep, old chap, and when you’re well enough - what larks! And PIP smiles, closes his eyes and sleeps again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A frail PIP and JOE sit at a makeshift tea-chest table, eating chunks of bread and butter.

dialogues.speaker: PIP
dialogues.text: How long have I been ill, Joe?

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: It’s the end of May. Matter of a month or so?

dialogues.speaker: PIP
dialogues.text: And you've been with me all that time?

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: A good part of it.  GREAT EXPECTATIONS (PAGES 10/12) 107.

dialogues.speaker: PIP
dialogues.text: Miss Havisham, Joe - is she dead?

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: I wouldn’t go as far as to say that, but she ain’t...

dialogues.speaker: PIP
dialogues.text: ...-living, Joe?

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: She ain’t living.

dialogues.speaker: PIP
dialogues.text: Do you know what happened to her property, Joe?

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: It went to Miss Estella and her -

dialogues.speaker: PIP
dialogues.text: Her husband.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: That’s the one. Her husband. And there it is. PIP rises slowly and retreats to the bedroom. A moment, then JOE follows on -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PIP sits and stares at the wall of the barren room.

dialogues.speaker: PIP
dialogues.text: I have nothing, Joe. No money, no profession, no expectations or hope for the future. Everything of worth has slipped through my fingers.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Not everything I hope, dear chap. And JOE nudges him with his shoulder. PIP manages a smile

dialogues.speaker: PIP
dialogues.text: We have had times together, Joe, that I can never forget. I did for a while forget, but not any more.

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Pip, there have been larks. And what have been betwixt us - have been. And the two friends continue to sit in silence.  203 204 205 206 207 208 GREAT EXPECTATIONS (PAGES 10/12) 108.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PIP wakes once more. The apartment is empty - something i wrong.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On the mantelpiece, a pile of papers. Bills and invoices, all PIP’s debts. All marked with the same words - ‘Paid in Full’. And a note, written in a rudimentary hand. ‘have departed fur you are well dear pip join me sunday for larks ever best of friends J’

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In sturdy, sensible boots, PIP strides across the marshes of his youth towards his old home. It's a beautiful June day, and he carries everything he owns in a back-pack. The gibbet hangs over the road. PIP hesitates, but only momentarily. Then he marches beneath it, fearless now. In the distance, smoke rises from the forge. PIP breaks into a run...

dialogues.speaker: EXT/INT. GARGERY HOUSE
dialogues.text: PIP is about to enter the kitchen, when he sees a figure through the window. He hesitates... BIDDY, his childhood sweetheart, is arranging flowers on the table. PIP watches for a moment, smiling affectionately, the ghost of a romantic feeling reviving within him. BIDDY wears her Sunday best, and has a glow about her that he hasn’t seen before. PIP steps into the doorway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 209 210 GREAT EXPECTATIONS (PAGES 10/12) 109.

dialogues.speaker: PIP
dialogues.text: Biddy? I came to see you as quickly as I could. I wanted to tell you, Biddy - She turns, puts her hand to her mouth, startled, the flowers still clasped in her other hand; a bouquet. And PIP realises -

dialogues.speaker: BIDDY
dialogues.text: Oh, Pip - it’s my wedding day! For one tiny moment, there’s a flicker of disappointment on his face. But then JOE is there, beaming in his Sunday best, and PI rushes in, embracing them both and laughing, laughing...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: After the ceremony, the newly weds and their only guest head for their old spot. JOE gives BIDDY a piggy-back, PI follows on, watching them with pleasure. Perhaps she even throws him her bouquet...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the sun goes down, the three friends sit side-by-side in their old spot, BIDDY and JOE still in their wedding finery.

dialogues.speaker: PIP
dialogues.text: Your life savings, Joe!

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: It's only money, Pip.

dialogues.speaker: PIP
dialogues.text: Nevertheless, I will work and work and I will pay you back, every last penny, if it takes me...

dialogues.speaker: JOE
dialogues.text: Enough now. BIDDY smiles, takes JOE’s hand, looks to PIP. And the three friends sit there, watching as the sun goes down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A letter, sealed in red wax.  211 212 213 GREAT EXPECTATIONS (PAGES 10/12) 110. It is held in the hand of a young ENGLISH BOY, seven year old, clutching it tightly as he hurtles through the back streets.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The BOY finds a staircase in amongst the tangle of alleys and clambers up the stairs to -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The modest, somewhat ramshackle offices of CLARRIKER- POCKET IMPORT-EXPORT LIMITED. The BOY pushes open the door, and rushes in. Silks, rugs, imports from the East festoon the room.

dialogues.speaker: HERBERT
dialogues.text: Knock! Goodness, Charles, how many times have I told you, this is a place of business, not a nursery! HERBERT scoops his son up onto his lap.

dialogues.speaker: CHARLES
dialogues.text: I have a message. From a lady...

dialogues.speaker: HERBERT
dialogues.text: A lady, how intriguing! (calling out) It’s from a lady, Handel! And PIP enters the room. Older, darker, more mature, he smiles and takes the note from CHARLES, opens it, reads it. And sits down in silence.

dialogues.speaker: HERBERT
dialogues.text: What is it, Handel? Handel?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PIP strides through the wintery park, full of anticipation. She stands at their meeting place, her back towards him. PIP watches for a moment, too scared to approach, gathering his nerve. But she senses he is there, and turns. She is still beautiful, but the once proud eyes have a saddened, softened quality.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 214 GREAT EXPECTATIONS (PAGES 10/12) lll. ESTELLA smiles - a smile that’s also sad, softened - and holds out her hand to PIP.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PIP and ESTELLA sit. A comfortable silence, broken eventually.

dialogues.speaker: ESTELLA
dialogues.text: He died. Two years ago. He was beating his horse, and the horse had the good taste to kick him in the head.

dialogues.speaker: PIP
dialogues.text: I’m sorry to hear that.

dialogues.speaker: ESTELLA
dialogues.text: Pip, I know you too well for you to pretend a sorrow you do not feel.

dialogues.speaker: PIP
dialogues.text: I’m sorry for anything that brings you sorrow.

dialogues.speaker: ESTELLA
dialogues.text: Then rest assured I feel none. My husband and I made each other perfectly miserable, just as intended. (a shrug, a wry smile) I have been bent and broken, but I hope into a better shape

dialogues.speaker: PIP
dialogues.text: Do you think that you might...marry again? ESTELLA doesn’t answer.

dialogues.speaker: ESTELLA
dialogues.text: I’ve been abroad a great deal, travelling through the East, Africa, Arabia. I had heard that you were here, and thriving and I had a desire to see...my old friend. My only friend. (She takes his hand) When we last met, you said that you would always think of me -

dialogues.speaker: PIP
dialogues.text: And I have -

dialogues.speaker: ESTELLA
dialogues.text: - that you would always think of the good in me. 214  GREAT EXPECTATIONS (PAGES 10/12) 111A.

dialogues.speaker: PIP
dialogues.text: I do. Always. You are a part of me, Estella.  GREAT EXPECTATIONS (PAGES 10/12) 112.

dialogues.speaker: ESTELLA
dialogues.text: ‘You are in the ships’, you said, ‘and the river.’ She looks at him for a long time.

dialogues.speaker: PIP
dialogues.text: I love you, Estella. A moment.

dialogues.speaker: ESTELLA
dialogues.text: I am glad. FADE TO BLACK.
